revision.text:
{{About|the '''history of the study of speciation'''|a broader description of the biological phenomenon|Speciation}} [[File:Charles Darwin by Julia Margaret Cameron 2.jpg|thumb|[[Charles Darwin]] in 1868]] {{Evolutionary biology}} The scientific study of [[speciation]] — how [[species]] evolve to become new species — began around the time of [[Charles Darwin]] in the middle of the 19th century. Many naturalists at the time recognized the relationship between [[biogeography]] (the way species are distributed) and the [[evolution]] of species. The 20th century saw the growth of the field of speciation, with major contributors such as [[Ernst Mayr]] researching and documenting species' geographic patterns and relationships. The field grew in prominence with the [[Modern synthesis (20th century)|modern evolutionary synthesis]] in the early part of that century. Since then, research on speciation has expanded immensely.
The language of speciation has grown more complex. Debate over classification schemes on the mechanisms of speciation and [[reproductive isolation]] continue. The 21st century has seen a resurgence in the study of speciation, with new techniques such as molecular [[phylogenetics]] and [[systematics]]. Speciation has largely been divided into discrete modes that correspond to rates of gene flow between two incipient populations. Today however, research has driven the development of alternative schemes and the discovery of new processes of speciation.
== Early history == [[File:On the Origin of Species diagram.PNG|thumb|The only figure in Darwin's 1859 ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'', a tree of lineages splitting to form new species<ref name="Mallet2008"/>]]
[[Charles Darwin]] introduced the idea that species could evolve and split into separate lineages, referring to it as ''specification'' in his 1859 book ''[[On the Origin of Species]]''.<ref name="Singh2012">{{Citation |title=Concepts of species and modes of speciation | author=B. N. Singh | journal=Current Science | year=2012 | volume=103 | issue=7 | pages=784–790 }}</ref> It was not until 1906 that the modern term ''speciation'' was coined by the biologist [[Orator F. Cook]].<ref name="Singh2012"/><ref>{{cite journal |last=Cook |first=Orator F. |authorlink=Orator F. Cook |date=March 30, 1906 |title=Factors of species-formation |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] |volume=23 |issue=587 |pages=506–507 |doi=10.1126/science.23.587.506 |issn=0036-8075 |pmid=17789700}}</ref> Darwin, in his 1859 publication, focused primarily on the changes that can occur within a species, and less on how species may divide into two.<ref name="Speciation">{{Citation | title=Speciation | author1=Jerry A. Coyne |author1link=Jerry Coyne |author2=H. Allen Orr |author2link=H. Allen Orr | date=2004 | pages=1–545 | publisher=Sinauer Associates | isbn=0-87893-091-4 }}</ref>{{rp|1}} It is almost universally accepted that Darwin's book did not directly address its title.<ref name="Mallet2008">{{Citation | title=A century of evolution: Ernst Mayr (1904-2005): Mayr's view of Darwin: was Darwin wrong about speciation? | author=James Mallet | journal=Biological Journal of the Linnean Society | year=2008 | volume=95 | issue=1 | pages=3–16 | doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.2008.01089.x | url=https://academic.oup.com/biolinnean/article/95/1/3/2701309 | deadurl=no | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203072521/https://academic.oup.com/biolinnean/article/95/1/3/2701309 | archive-date=2018-02-03 | df= }}</ref> Darwin instead saw speciation as occurring by species entering new [[ecological niche]]s.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|125}}
=== Darwin's views === Controversy exists as to whether [[Charles Darwin]] recognized a true geographical-based model of speciation in his publication ''On the Origin of Species''.<ref name=Mallet2010/> In chapter 11, "Geographical Distribution", Darwin discusses geographic barriers to migration, stating for example that "barriers of any kind, or obstacles to free migration, are related in a close and important manner to the differences between the productions of various regions [of the world]".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Darwin |first1=Charles |title=On the Origin of Species |date=1859 |publisher=Murray |page=347 |url=http://darwin-online.org.uk/content/frameset?itemID=F373&viewtype=text&pageseq=1 |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005185317/http://darwin-online.org.uk/content/frameset?itemID=F373&viewtype=text&pageseq=1 |archive-date=2008-10-05 |df= }}</ref> F. J. Sulloway contends that Darwin's position on speciation was "misleading" at the least<ref>{{Citation |title=Geographic isolation in Darwin's thinking: the vicissitudes of a crucial idea | author=F. J. Sulloway | journal=Studies in the History of Biology | year=1979 | volume=3 | issue= | pages=23–65 | pmid=11610987 }}</ref> and may have later misinformed Wagner and David Starr Jordan into believing that Darwin viewed sympatric speciation as the most important mode of speciation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|83}} Nevertheless, Darwin never fully accepted Wagner's concept of geographical speciation.<ref name=Mallet2010/>
The evolutionary biologist [[James Mallet]] maintains that the mantra repeated concerning Darwin's ''Origin of Species'' book having never actually discussed speciation is specious.<ref name="Mallet2008"/> The claim began with [[Thomas Henry Huxley]] and [[George Romanes]] (contemporaries of Darwin's), who declared that Darwin failed to explain the origins of inviability and sterility in hybrids.<ref name="Mallet2008"/><ref name="Mallet2013">Mallet, James (2013). Darwin and species. In Michael Ruse (eds) ''The Cambridge Encyclopedia of Darwin and Evolutionary Thought'', Cambridge University Press, Pp. 109–115.</ref> Similar claims were promulgated by the [[Mutationism|mutationist]] school of thought during the late 20th century, and even after the [[Modern synthesis (20th century)|modern evolutionary synthesis]] by [[Richard Goldschmidt]].<ref name="Mallet2008"/><ref name="Mallet2013"/> Another strong proponent of this view about Darwin came from Mayr.<ref name="Mallet2008"/><ref name="Mallet2013"/> Mayr maintained that Darwin was unable to address the problem of speciation, as he did not define species using the biological species concept.<ref name="Kottler1978">{{Citation |title=Charles Darwin's biological species concept and theory of geographic speciation: the transmutation notebooks |author=Malcolm J. Kottler |journal=Annals of Science |year=1978 |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=275–297 |doi=10.1080/00033797800200251 }}</ref> However, Mayr's view has not been entirely accepted, as Darwin's transmutation notebooks contained writings concerning the role of isolation in the splitting of species.<ref name="Kottler1978"/> Furthermore, Many of Darwin's ideas on speciation largely match the modern theories of both [[adaptive radiation]] and [[ecological speciation]].<ref name=Mallet2010/>
== Biogeographic influence == [[File:Moritz Wagner - Geograph und Naturforscher.jpg|thumb|upright|The German traveller [[Moritz Wagner]] (1813–1887)]] {{see also|Geographic speciation}} Recognition of geographic factors involved in species populations was present even before Darwin, with many naturalists aware of the role of isolation in species relationships.<ref name="Mayr1963">{{Citation | title=Animal Species and Evolution | edition= | author=Ernst Mayr | date=1963 | pages=1–797 | publisher=Harvard University Press | isbn= }}</ref>{{rp|482}} In 1833, [[C. L. Gloger]] published ''The Variation of Birds Under the Influence of Climate'' in which he described geographic variations, but did not recognize that geographic isolation was an indicator of past speciation events.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|482}} Another naturalist in 1856, [[Thomas Vernon Wollaston|Wollaston]], studied island beetles in comparison to mainland species.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|482}} He saw isolation as key to their differentiation.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|482}} However, he did not recognize that the pattern was due to speciation.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|483}} One naturalist, [[Christian Leopold von Buch|Leopold von Buch]] (1825) did recognize the geographic patterns and explicitly stated that geographic isolation may lead to species separating into new species.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|483}} Mayr suggests that Von Buch was likely the first naturalist to truly suggest geographic speciation.<ref>{{Citation | title=The Evolutionary Synthesis: Perspectives on the Unification of Biology | edition= | author=Ernst Mayr | date=1998 | pages=36 | publisher=Harvard University Press | isbn=978-0674272262 }}</ref> Other naturalists, such as [[Henry Walter Bates]] (1863), recognized and accepted the patterns as evidence of speciation, but in Bate's case, did not propose a coherent model.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|484}}
In 1868, [[Moritz Wagner]] was the first to propose the concept of geographic speciation<ref name=Jordan1905>{{Citation |title=The Origin of Species Through Isolation | author=David Starr Jordan | journal=Science | year=1905 | volume=22 | issue=566 | pages=545–562 }}</ref><ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|484}} in which he used the term ''Separationstheorie''.<ref name=Mallet2010>{{Citation |title=Why was Darwin’s view of species rejected by twentieth century biologists? | author=James Mallet | journal=Biology & Philosophy | year=2010 | volume=25 | pages=497–527 | doi=10.1007/s10539-010-9213-7 }}</ref> [[Edward Bagnall Poulton]], the evolutionary biologist and a strong proponent of the importance of natural selection, highlighted the role of geographic isolation in promoting speciation,<ref name="Modes and Mechanisms of Speciation">{{Citation |title=Modes and Mechanisms of Speciation | author=Hannes Schuler, Glen R. Hood, Scott P. Egan, and Jeffrey L. Feder | journal=Reviews in Cell Biology and Molecular Medicine | year=2016 | volume=2 | issue=3 | pages=60–93 | doi=10.1002/3527600906.mcb.201600015}}</ref> in the process coining the term "sympatric speciation" in 1904.<ref>{{Citation | title=Systematics and origin of species | edition= | author=Ernst Mayr | date=1942 | pages=148 | publisher=Columbia University Press | isbn= }}</ref><ref name="Mallet2003">{{Citation |title=Perspectives: Poulton, Wallace and Jordan: how discoveries in Papilio butterflies led to a new species concept 100 years ago | author=James Mallet| authorlink=James Mallet | journal=Systematics and Biodiversity | year=2004 | volume=1 | issue=4 | pages=441–452 | doi=10.1017/S1477200003001300 }}</ref>
Wagner and other naturalists who studied the geographic distributions of animals, such as [[Karl Jordan]] and [[David Starr Jordan]], noticed that closely related species were often geographically isolated from one another (allopatrically distributed) which lead to the advocation of the importance of geographic isolation in the origin of species.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|2}} Karl Jordan is thought to have recognized the unification of mutation and isolation in the origin of new species — in stark contrast to the prevailing views at the time.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|486}} David Starr Jordan reiterated Wagner's proposal in 1905, providing a wealth of evidence from nature to support the theory,<ref name="Jordan1905"/><ref>{{Citation |title=The Law of Geminate Species | author=David Starr Jordan | journal=American Naturalist | year=1908 | volume=42 | pages=73–80 }}</ref><ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|2}} and asserting that geographic isolation is obvious but had been unfortunately ignored by most geneticists and experimental evolutionary biologists at the time.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|487}} [[Joel Asaph Allen]] suggested the observed pattern of geographic separation of closely related species be called "Jordan's Law" (or Wagner's Law).<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|487}} Despite the contentions, most taxonomists did accept the geographic model of speciation.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|487}}
Many of the early terms used to describe speciation were outlined by Ernst Mayr.<ref name="Harrison2012">{{Citation |title=The Language of Speciation | author=Richard G. Harrison | journal=Evolution | year=2012 | volume=66 | issue=12 | pages=3643–3657 | doi=10.1111/j.1558-5646.2012.01785.x }}</ref> He was the first to encapsulate the then contemporary literature in his 1942 publication ''[[Systematics and the Origin of Species|Systematics and the Origin of Species, from the Viewpoint of a Zoologist]]'' and in his subsequent 1963 publication ''[[Animal Species and Evolution]]''. Like Jordan's works, they relied on direct observations of nature, documenting the occurrence of geographic speciation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|86}} He described the three modes: geographic, semi-geographic, and non-geographic; which today, are referred to as allopatric, parapatric, and sympatric respectively.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> Mayr's 1942 publication, influenced heavily by the ideas of Karl Jordan and Poulton, was regarded as the authoritative review of speciation for over 20 years—and is still valuable today.<ref name="Mallet2003"/>
A major focus of Mayr's works was on the importance of geography in facilitating speciation; with islands often acting as a central theme to many of the speciation concepts put forth.<ref>{{Citation |title=A century of evolution: Ernst Mayr (1904–2005): Speciation on islands: what are we learning? | author=Brent C. Emerson | journal=Biological Journal of the Linnean Society | year=2008 | volume=95 | issue=1 | pages=47–52 | doi= }}</ref> One of which was the concept of [[peripatric speciation]], a variant of allopatric speciation<ref>Mayr, E. 1954. Change of genetic environment and evolution. In: ''Evolution as a Process'' (J. Huxley, A. C. Hardy & E. B. Ford, eds), pp. 157–180. Unwin Brothers, London.</ref><ref>Mayr, E. 1982. Processes of speciation in animals. In: ''Mechanisms of Speciation'' (A. R. I. Liss, ed.), pp. 1–19. Alan R. Liss Inc., New York.</ref> (he has since distinguished the two modes by referring to them as peripatric and dichopatric<ref>{{Citation | title=What Evolution Is | edition= | author=Ernst Mayr | date=2001 | pages=178–179 | publisher=Basic Books | isbn=0465044263 }}</ref>). This concept arose by an interpretation of Wagner's ''Separationstheorie'' as a form of [[founder effect]] speciation that focused on small geographically isolated species.<ref name=Mallet2010/> This model was later expanded and modified to incorporate [[sexual selection]] by [[Kenneth Y. Kaneshiro]] in 1976 and 1980.<ref name=KYK1976>{{Citation |title=Ethological isolation and phylogeny in the Plantibia subgroup of Hawaiian ''Drosophila'' | author=Kenneth Y. Kaneshiro | journal=Evolution | year=1976 | volume=30 | issue= 4| pages=740–745 | doi= 10.1111/j.1558-5646.1976.tb00954.x| pmid=28563322 }}</ref><ref name=KYK1980>{{Citation |title=Sexual selection, speciation and the direction of evolution | author=Kenneth Y. Kaneshiro | journal=Evolution | year=1980 | volume=34 | issue= 3| pages=437–444 | doi= 10.1111/j.1558-5646.1980.tb04833.x| pmid=28568697 }}</ref><ref name=AO&ABF2002>{{Citation |title=Sexual selection and peripatric speciation: the Kaneshiro model revisited | author=Anders Ödeen and Ann-Britt Florin | journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology | year=2002 | volume=15 | issue= | pages=301–306 | doi= }}</ref>
== Modern evolutionary synthesis == {{main|Modern synthesis (20th century)}} Many geneticists at the time did little to bridge the gap between the genetics of natural selection and the origin of reproductive barriers between species.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|3}} [[Ronald Fisher]] proposed a model of speciation in his 1930 publication ''[[The Genetical Theory of Natural Selection]]'', where he described disruptive selection acting on sympatric or parapatric populations — with reproductive isolation completed by reinforcement.<ref name="Coyne1994"/> Other geneticists such as [[J. B. S. Haldane]] did not even recognize that species were real, while [[Sewall Wright]] ignored the topic, despite accepting allopatric speciation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|3}}
The primary contributors to the incorporation of speciation into modern evolutionary synthesis were Ernst Mayr and [[Theodosius Dobzhansky]].<ref name="Coyne1994">{{Citation |title=Ernst Mayr and the origin of species | author=Jerry A. Coyne | journal=Evolution | year=1994 | volume=48 | issue=1 | pages=19–30| doi=10.1111/j.1558-5646.1994.tb01290.x |pmid=28567778 }}</ref> Dobzhansky, a geneticist, published ''[[Genetics and the Origin of Species]]'' in 1937, in which he formulated the genetic framework for how speciation could occur.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|2}} He recognized that speciation was an unsolved problem in biology at the time, rejecting Darwin’s position that new species arose by occupation of new niches — contending that reproductive isolation was instead based on barriers to gene flow.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|2}} Subsequently, Mayr conducted extensive work on the geography of species, emphasizing the importance of geographic separation and isolation, in which he filled Dobzhansky‘s gaps concerning the origin of biodiversity (in his 1942 book).<ref name="Mayr2004">{{Citation | title=80 years of watching the evolutionary scenery | author=Ernst Mayr | journal=Science | year=2004 | volume=305 | issue=5680 | pages=46–47 | doi=10.1126/science.1100561 | url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/305/5680/46.full.pdf | deadurl=no | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203071559/http://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/305/5680/46.full.pdf | archive-date=2018-02-03 | df= }}</ref> Both of their works gave rise, not without controversy, to the modern understanding of speciation; stimulating a wealth of research on the topic.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|3}} Furthermore, this extended to plants as well as animals with [[G. Ledyard Stebbins]]’s book, ''[[Variation and Evolution in Plants]]'' and the much later, 1981 book, ''[[Plant Speciation]]'' by [[Verne Grant]].
[[File:Ernst Mayr PLoS.jpg|thumb|[[Ernst Mayr]], an influential evolutionary biologist<ref>{{Citation | title=A century of evolution: Ernst Mayr (1904–2005): Introduction | author=Michael F. Clairidge and Vaughan Southgate | journal=Biological Journal of the Linnean Society | year=2008 | volume=95 | issue=1 | pages=1–2 | doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.2008.01119.x | url=https://academic.oup.com/biolinnean/article/95/1/1/2701381 | deadurl=no | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203071431/https://academic.oup.com/biolinnean/article/95/1/1/2701381 | archive-date=2018-02-03 | df= }}</ref>]]
In 1947, "a consensus had been achieved among geneticists, paleontologists and systematists and that evolutionary biology as an independent biological discipline had been established" during a Princeton University conference.<ref name="Haffer2007">{{Citation | title=Ornithology, Evolution, and Philosophy: The Life and Science of Ernst Mayr 1904–2005 | edition= | author=Jürgen Haffer | date=2007 | pages=183–241 | publisher=Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg | isbn=978-3-540-71777-5 }}</ref> This 20th century synthesis incorporated speciation. Since then, the ideas have been consistently and repeatedly confirmed.<ref name="Mayr2004"/>
== Contemporary work == After the synthesis, speciation research continued largely within natural history and biogeography — with much less emphasis on genetics.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|4}} The study of speciation has seen its largest increase since the 1980s<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|4}} with an influx of publications and a host of new terms, methods, concepts, and theories.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> This "third phase" of work — as [[Jerry Coyne|Jerry A. Coyne]] and [[H. Allen Orr]] put it — has led to a growing complexity of the language used to describe the many processes of speciation.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> The research and literature on speciation have become, "enormous, scattered, and increasingly technical".<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|1}}
From the 1980s, new research tools increased the robustness of research,<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|4}} assisted by new methods, theoretical frameworks, models, and approaches.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> Coyne and Orr discuss the modern, post-1980s developments centered around five major themes: # genetics (also a primary factor in the Modern Synthesis), # [[molecular biology]] and analysis (namely, [[phylogenetics]] and [[systematics]]); # comparative analysis; # mathematical modeling and computer simulations; and # the role of [[ecology]].<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|5}}
Ecologists became aware that the ecological factors behind speciation were under-represented. This saw the growth in research concerning ecology's role in facilitating speciation — rightly designated [[ecological speciation]].<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|4}} This focus on ecology generated a host of new terms relating to the barriers to reproduction<ref name="Harrison2012"/> (''e.g.'' allochronic speciation, in which gene flow is reduced or removed by timing of breeding periods; or habitat isolation, in which species occupy different habitats within the same area). [[Sympatric speciation]], regarded by Mayr as unlikely, has become widely accepted.<ref name="Theory and speciation">{{Citation |title=Theory and speciation | author=Michael Turelli| author2=Nicholas H. Barton| author3=Jerry A. Coyne |author3link=Jerry A. Coyne | journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution | year=2001 | volume=16 | issue=7 | pages=330–343 }}</ref><ref name="Via2001">{{Citation |title=Sympatric speciation in animals: the ugly duckling grows up | author=Sara Via | journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution | year=2001 | volume=16 | issue=1 | pages=381–390 | pmid=11403871 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0169-5347(01)02188-7 }}</ref><ref name="Mallet2001">{{Citation |title=The Speciation Revolution | author=James Mallet |authorlink=James Mallet | journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology | year=2001 | volume=14 | issue=6 | pages=887–888 | doi=10.1046/j.1420-9101.2001.00342.x }}</ref> Research on the influence of natural selection on speciation, including the process of [[Reinforcement (speciation)|reinforcement]], has grown.<ref name="Noor1999">{{Citation |title=Reinforcement and other consequences of sympatry | author=Mohamed A. F. Noor | journal=Heredity | year=1999 | volume=83 | issue= | pages=503–508 | doi= | pmid=10620021}}</ref>
Researchers have long debated the roles of [[sexual selection]], natural selection, and [[genetic drift]] in speciation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|383}} Darwin extensively discussed sexual selection, with his work greatly expanded on by Ronald Fisher; however, it was not until 1983 that the biologist [[Mary Jane West-Eberhard]] recognized the importance of sexual selection in speciation.<ref>{{Citation |title=2003 Sewall Wright Award: Mary Jane West‐Eberhard | author=Marlene Zuk | journal=American Naturalist | year=2004 | volume=163 | issue=1 | pages=i–ii | doi=10.1086/381946 }}</ref><ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|3}} Natural selection plays a role in that any selection towards reproductive isolation can result in speciation — whether indirectly or directly. Genetic drift has been widely researched from the 1950s onwards, especially with peak-shift models of speciation by genetic drift.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|388}} Mayr championed [[founder effect]]s, in which isolated individuals, like those found on islands near a mainland, experience a strong population bottleneck, as they contain only a small sample of the genetic variation in the main population.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|390}}<ref>Mayr, Ernst (1954). Change of genetic environment and evolution. In J. Huxley, A. C. Hardy, and E. B. Ford. (eds) ''Evolution as a Process'', George Allen and Unwin, London, Pp. 157–180.</ref> Later, other biologists such as [[Hampton L. Carson (biologist)|Hampton L. Carson]], [[Alan Templeton]], [[Sergey Gavrilets]], and [[Alan Hastings]] developed related models of speciation by genetic drift, noting that islands were inhabited mostly by endemic species.<ref>[[Will Provine|Provine, William Ball]] (1989). Founder effects and genetic revolutions in microevolution and speciation. In L. V. Giddings, K. Y. Kaneshiro, and W. W. Anderson. (eds) ''Genetics, Speciation, and the Founder Principle'', Oxford University Press, New York, Pp. 43–76.</ref> Selection's role in speciation is widely supported, whereas founder effect speciation is not,<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|410}} having been subject to a number of criticisms.<ref>{{Citation |title=The role of founder effects on the evolution of reproductive isolation |author= |journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology |year=2013 |volume=26 |pages=2299–2311 |doi=10.1111/jeb.12246 }}</ref>
=== Classification debate === [[File:Speciation (Gene flow continuum).png|left|thumb|350px|Speciation represented as a continuum of gene flow where <math>m</math> equals the rate of gene exchange. The three primary geographic modes of speciation ([[Allopatric speciation|allopatric]], [[Parapatric speciation|parapatric]], and [[Sympatric speciation|sympatric]]) can exist within this continuum, as well as other non-geographic modes.]] Throughout the history of research concerning speciation, classification and delineation of modes and processes have been debated. [[Julian Huxley]] divided speciation into three separate modes: geographical speciation, genetic speciation, and ecological speciation.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|427}} Sewall Wright proposed ten different, varying modes.<ref name="Mayr1963"/>{{rp|427}} Ernst Mayr championed the importance of physical, geographic separation of species populations, maintaining it to be of major importance to speciation. He originally proposed the three primary modes known today: geographic, semi-geographic, non-geographic;<ref name="Harrison2012"/> corresponding to allopatric, parapatric, and sympatric respectively.
The phrase "modes of speciation" is imprecisely defined, most often indicating speciation occurring as a result of a species geographic distribution.<ref name="eLS2012Shaw">{{cite journal | last =Shaw | first =Kerry L. | title =Species and Speciation: Overview | journal =eLS | publisher =John Wiley & Sons Ltd | location =Chichester | date =2012 | url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001742.pub2/abstract | doi =10.1002/9780470015902.a0001742.pub2 | deadurl =no | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20180125135943/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001742.pub2/abstract | archive-date =2018-01-25 | df = }}</ref> More succinctly, the modern classification of speciation is often described as occurring on a gene flow continuum (i.e., allopatry at <math>m=0</math> and sympatry at <math>m=0.5</math><ref name="Gavrilets2004">{{Citation | title=Fitness landscapes and the origin of species | edition= | author=Sergey Gavrilets | date=2004 | pages=13 | publisher=Princeton University Press | isbn= }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=Perspectiver: Models of Speciation: What have we Learned in 40 Years? |author=Sergey Gavrilets |journal=Evolution |year=2003 |volume=57 |issue=10 |pages=2197–2215 |doi=10.1111/j.0014-3820.2003.tb00233.x |pmid=14628909 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.0014-3820.2003.tb00233.x/epdf |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211160348/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.0014-3820.2003.tb00233.x/epdf |archive-date=2018-02-11 |df= }}</ref>) This gene flow concept views speciation as based on the exchange of genes between populations instead of seeing a purely geographic setting as necessarily relevant. Despite this, concepts of biogeographic modes can be translated into models of gene flow (such as that in the image at left); however, this translation has led to some confusion of language in the scientific literature.<ref name="Harrison2012"/>
[[File:Speciation modes.svg|Right|thumb|260px|Comparisons of the three classic geographic modes of speciation: [[allopatric speciation|allopatric]], [[parapatric speciation|parapatric]] and [[sympatric speciation|sympatric]]; with [[peripatric speciation]] included as a special case of allopatric speciation.]] As research has expanded over the decades, the geographic scheme has been challenged. The traditional classification is considered by some researchers to be obsolete,<ref name="Fitzpatrick2009">{{Citation |title=Pattern, process, and geographic modes of speciation | author=Benjamin M. Fitzpatrick, James A. Fordyce, and Sergey Gavrilets | journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology | year=2009 | volume=22 | issue=11 | pages=2342–2347 | doi=10.1111/j.1420-9101.2009.01833.x }}</ref> while others argue for its merits. Proponents of non-geographic schemes often justify non-geographic classifications, not by rejection of the importance of reproductive isolation (or even the processes themselves), but instead by the fact that it simplifies the complexity of speciation.<ref name="Butlin2008">{{Citation | title=Sympatric, parapatric or allopatric: the most important way to classify speciation? | author=Roger K. Butlin, Juan Galindo, and John W. Grahame | journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | year=2008 | volume=363 | issue=1506 | pages=2997–3007 | doi=10.1098/rstb.2008.0076 | pmid=18522915 | url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/363/1506/2997 | deadurl=no | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134419/http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/363/1506/2997 | archive-date=2018-01-25 | df= | pmc=2607313 }}</ref> One major critique of the geographic framework is that it arbitrarily separates a biological continuum into discontinuous groups.<ref name="Butlin2008"/> Another criticism rests with the fact that, when speciation is viewed as a continuum of gene flow, parapatric speciation becomes unreasonably represented by the entire continuum<ref name="Fitzpatrick2008">{{Citation |title=What, if anything, is sympatric speciation? | author=Benjamin M. Fitzpatrick, James A. Fordyce, and Sergey Gavrilets | journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology | year=2009 | volume=21 | issue=6 | pages=1452–1459 | doi=10.1111/j.1420-9101.2008.01611.x }}</ref>—with allopatric and sympatric existing in the extremes.<ref name="Butlin2008" /> Coyne and Orr argue that the geographic classification scheme is valuable in that biogeography controls the strength of the evolutionary forces at play, as gene flow and geography are clearly linked.<ref name="Fitzpatrick2009"/> James Mallet and colleagues contend that the sympatric vs. allopatric dichotomy is valuable to determine the degree in which natural selection acts on speciation.<ref>{{Citation |title=Space, sympatry and speciation | author=James Mallet, Axel Meyer, Patrik Nosil, Jeffrey L. Feder | journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology | year=2009 | volume=22 | issue=11 | pages= 2332–2341 | doi=10.1111/j.1420-9101.2009.01816.x }}</ref> Kirkpatrick and Ravigné categorize speciation in terms of its genetic basis or by the forces driving reproductive isolation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|85}} Here, the geographic modes of speciation are classified as types of assortive mating.<ref>{{Citation |title=Speciation by Natural and Sexual Selection: Models and Experiments | author=Mark Kirkpatrick | author2=Virginie Ravigné | journal=The American Naturalist | year=2002 | volume=159 | doi=10.1086/338370 }}</ref> Fitzpatrick and colleagues believe that the biogeographic scheme "is a distraction that could be positively misleading if the real goal is to understand the influence of natural selection on divergence."<ref name="Fitzpatrick2009" /> They maintain that, to fully understand speciation, "the spatial, ecological, and genetic factors" involved in divergence must be explored.<ref name="Fitzpatrick2009" /> Sara Via recognizes the importance of geography in speciation but suggests that classification under this scheme be abandoned.<ref name="Via2001"/>
== History of modes and mechanisms == === Sympatric speciation === [[Sympatric speciation]], from its beginnings with Darwin (who did not coin the term), has been a contentious issue.<ref name="eLS2012Shaw"/><ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|125}} Mayr, along with many other evolutionary biologists, interpreted Darwins's view of speciation and the origin of biodiversity as arising by species entering new [[ecological niche]]s—a form of sympatric speciation.<ref name="Mallet2008"/> Before Mayr, sympatric speciation was regarded as the primary mode of speciation. In 1963, Mayr provided a strong criticism, citing various flaws in the theory.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|126}} After that, sympatric speciation fell out of favor with biologists and has only recently seen a resurgence in interest.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|126}} Some biologists, such as James Mallet, believe that Darwin's view on speciation was misunderstood and misconstrued by Mayr.<ref name="Mallet2008"/><ref>{{Citation |title=Speciation in the 21st century | author=James Mallet | journal=Heredity | year=2005 | volume=95 | issue=1 | pages=105–109 | doi=10.1038/sj.hdy.6800686 | issn=0018-067X }}</ref> Today, sympatric speciation is supported by evidence from laboratory experiments and observations from nature.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|127}}<ref name="Theory and speciation"/>
=== Hybrid speciation === For most of the history of speciation, hybridization (polyploidy) has been a contentious issue, as botanists and zoologists have traditionally viewed hybridization's role in speciation differently.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> [[Carl Linnaeus]] was the earliest to suggest hybridization in 1760,<ref name="eLS2012Abbott">{{cite journal | last=Abbott | first=Richard J. | last2=Reiseberg | first2=Loren H. | title=Hybrid Speciation | journal=eLS | publisher=John Wiley & Sons Ltd | location=Chichester | date=2012 | url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001753.pub2/abstract | doi=10.1002/9780470015902.a0001753.pub2 | deadurl=no | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707151410/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001753.pub2/abstract | archive-date=2017-07-07 | df= }}</ref> [[Øjvind Winge]] was the first to confirm allopolyploidy in 1917,<ref name="eLS2012Abbott"/><ref>{{Citation |title=Interspecific Hybridization in Nicotiana. II. a Tetraploid ''GLUTINOSA-TABACUM'' Hybrid, an Experimental Verification of Winge's Hypothesis |author=R. E. Clausen and T. H. Goodspeed |journal=Genetics |year=1925 |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=278–284 |pmc=1200860 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1200860/pdf/278.pdf |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211160349/https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1200860/pdf/278.pdf |archive-date=2018-02-11 |df= }}</ref> and a later experiment conducted by Clausen and Goodspeed in 1925 confirmed the findings.<ref name="eLS2012Abbott"/> Today it is widely recognized as a common mechanism of speciation.<ref>{{Citation |title=What we still don’t know about polyploidy |author=Douglas E. Soltis, Richard J.A. Buggs, Jeff J. Doyle, and Pamela S. Soltis |journal=Taxon |year=2010 |volume=59 |issue=5 |pages=1387–1403 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2010/00000059/00000005/art00006 |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116232815/http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2010/00000059/00000005/art00006 |archive-date=2016-01-16 |df= }}</ref>
Historically, zoologists considered hybridization to be a rare phenomenon, while botanists found it to be commonplace in plant species.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> The botanists [[G. Ledyard Stebbins]] and [[Verne Grant]] were two of the well known botanists who championed the idea of hybrid speciation during the 1950s to the 1980s.<ref name="Harrison2012"/> Hybrid speciation, also called polyploid speciation (or polyploidy) is speciation that results by an increase in the number of sets of chromosomes.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|321}} It is effectively a form of sympatric speciation that happens instantly.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|322}} Grant coined the term [[recombinational speciation]] in 1981; a special form of hybrid speciation where a new species results from hybridization and is itself, reproductively isolated from both its parents.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|337}} Recently, biologists have increasingly recognized that hybrid speciation can occur in animals as well.<ref>{{Citation |title=Hybrid speciation |author=James Mallet |journal=Nature |year=2007 |volume=446 |issue=7133 |pages=279–283 |doi=10.1038/nature05706 |pmid=17361174 |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature05706 |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211160349/https://www.nature.com/articles/nature05706 |archive-date=2018-02-11 |df= }}</ref>
=== Reinforcement === [[File:Alfred Russel Wallace 1862 - Project Gutenberg eText 15997.png|thumb|right|150px|The young naturalist [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] in 1862]] The concept of [[Reinforcement (speciation)|speciation by reinforcement]] has a complex history, with its popularity among scholars changing significantly over time.<ref name="Noor1999"/><ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}} The theory of reinforcement experienced three phases of historical development:<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|366}} # plausibility based on unfit hybrids # implausibility based on the finding that hybrids may have some fitness # plausibility based on empirical studies and biologically complex and realistic models
It was originally proposed by [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] in 1889,<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}} termed the Wallace effect—a term rarely used by scientists today.<ref name="eLS2012">{{cite journal | last =Sætre | first =Glenn-Peter | title =Reinforcement | journal =eLS | publisher =John Wiley & Sons Ltd | location =Chichester | date =2012 | url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001754.pub3/abstract | doi =10.1002/9780470015902.a0001754.pub3 | deadurl =no | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20180211160349/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001754.pub3/abstract | archive-date =2018-02-11 | df = }}</ref> Wallace's hypothesis differed from the modern conception in that it focused on post-zygotic isolation, strengthened by [[group selection]].<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}}<ref>Littlejohn, M. J. (1981). Reproductive isolation: A critical review. In W. R. Atchley and D. S. Woodruff (eds) ''Evolution and Speciation'', Cambridge University Press, Pp. 298–334.</ref><ref>{{Citation | title=Natural Selection: Methods and Applications | author=Mario A. Fares | date=2015 | pages=3 | publisher=CRC Press | isbn=9781482263725 }}</ref> Dobzhansky was the first to provide a thorough, modern description of the process in 1937,<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}} though the actual term itself was not coined until 1955 by [[W. Frank Blair]].<ref>{{Citation |title=Mating call and stage of speciation in the ''Microhyla olivacea-M. carolinensis'' complex | author=Blair, W. Frank | journal=Evolution | year=1955 | volume=9 | issue= | pages=469–480 | doi= }}</ref>
In 1930, [[Ronald Fisher]] laid out the first genetic description of the process of reinforcement in ''[[The Genetical Theory of Natural Selection]]'', and in 1965 and 1970 the first computer simulations were run to test for its plausibility.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|366}} Later, population genetic<ref>{{Citation |title=On the evolution of behavioral reproductive isolation: The Wallace effect | author=Stanley Sawyer and Daniel Hartl | journal=Theoretical Population Biology | year=1981 | volume=19 | issue=1 | pages=261–273 | doi=10.1016/0040-5809(81)90021-6 }}</ref> and quantitative genetic<ref>{{Citation |title=A Two-Sex Polygenic Model for the Evolution of Premating Isolation. I. Deterministic Theory for Natural Populations | author=J. A. Sved | journal=Genetics | year=1981 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pages=197–215 | doi= }}</ref> studies were conducted showing that completely unfit hybrids lead to an increase in pre-zygotic isolation.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|368}} After Dobzhansky's idea rose to the forefront of speciation research, it garnered significant support—with Dobzhansky suggesting that it illustrated the final step in speciation (e.g. after an allopatric population comes into [[secondary contact]]).<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}} In the 1980s, many evolutionary biologists began to doubt the plausibility of the idea,<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|353}} based not on empirical evidence, but largely on the growth of theory that deemed it an unlikely mechanism of reproductive isolation.<ref name="Marshalletal2002">{{Citation |title=Reinforcement: the road not taken | author=Jeremy L. Marshall, Michael L. Arnold, and Daniel J. Howard | journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution | year=2002 | volume=17 | issue=12 | pages=558–563 | doi=10.1016/S0169-5347(02)02636-8 }}</ref> A number of theoretical objections arose at the time. Since the early 1990s, reinforcement has seen a revival in popularity, with perceptions by evolutionary biologists accepting its plausibility—due primarily from a sudden increase in data, empirical evidence from laboratory studies and nature, complex computer simulations, and theoretical work.<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|372–375}}
The scientific language concerning reinforcement has also differed over time, with different researchers applying various definitions to the term.<ref name="eLS2012"/> First used to describe the observed mating call differences in ''[[Gastrophryne]]'' frogs within a secondary contact hybrid zone,<ref name="eLS2012"/> reinforcement has also been used to describe geographically separated populations that experience secondary contact.<ref>{{Citation | title=Genetics And the Origin of Species | author=Theodosius Dobzhansky | date=1937 | publisher=Columbia University Press}}</ref> [[Roger Butlin]] demarcated incomplete post-zygotic isolation from complete isolation, referring to incomplete isolation as reinforcement and completely isolated populations as experiencing [[reproductive character displacement]].<ref name="Butlin1989">Butlin, Roger K. (1989). Reinforcement of premating isolation. In Otte, D. and Endler, John A. (eds) ''Speciation and its Consequences'', Sinauer Associates, pp. 158–179, {{ISBN|0-87893-657-2}}</ref> [[Daniel J. Howard]] considered reproductive character displacement to represent either [[assortive mating]] or the [[Genetic divergence|divergence]] of traits for mate recognition (specifically between sympatric populations).<ref name="eLS2012"/> Under this definition, it includes pre-zygotic divergence and complete post-zygotic isolation.<ref name="Howard1993">Howard, D. J. (1993). Reinforcement: origin, dynamics and fate of an evolutionary hypothesis. In: Harrison, R. G. (eds) ''Hybrid Zones and the Evolutionary Process'', Oxford University Press, pp. 46–69.</ref> [[Maria R. Servedio]] and [[Mohamed Noor]] consider any detected increase in pre-zygotic isolation as reinforcement, as long as it is a response to selection against mating between two different species.<ref name="Servedio&Noor">{{Citation |title=The Role of Reinforcement in Speciation: Theory and Data | author=Maria R. Servedio and Mohamed A. F. Noor | journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics | year=2003 | volume=34 | issue= | pages=339–364 | doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.34.011802.132412 }}</ref> Coyne and Orr contend that, "true reinforcement is restricted to cases in which isolation is enhanced between taxa that can still exchange genes".<ref name="Speciation"/>{{rp|354}}
== See also == * [[Laboratory experiments of speciation]]

revision.text:
{{See also|Australian Museum|James Cook}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox |name = Infobox/Museum Collections |bodystyle = |title = James Cook Collection |titlestyle = |image = [[File:H000104- Feather Cape.jpg|200px|H000104- Feather Cape]] |imagestyle = |caption = H000104- Feather Cape |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ccf; |labelstyle = |datastyle = |header1 = |label1 = Held by |data1 = The Australian Museum |header2 = |label2 = Location |data2 = Sydney, New South Wales Australia |header3 =Provenance |label3 = |data3 = |header4 = |label4 = Origin |data4 = Greater Pacific |header5 = |label5 = Source |data5 = Captain James Cook |herder6 = |label6 = Collected |data6 = c.1768- c.1780 |herder7 = |label7 = Website |data7 = [http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=35&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php Official website] }}
The [[Australian Museum]]'s '''''Cook Collection''''' was acquired in 1894 when it was transferred from the [[Government of New South Wales]]. At that time it consisted of 115 artifacts collected on [[Captain James Cook]]'s three voyages of discovery Throughout the [[Pacific Ocean]], during the period 1768 - 1780, along with documents and memorabilia related to these voyages. Many of the [[ethnographic]] artifacts were collected at a time of first contact between Pacific Peoples and [[Europeans]]. In 1935 most of the documents and memorabilia were transferred to the Mitchell Library in the [[State Library of New South Wales]]. The provenance of the collection shows that the objects remained in the hands of Captain James Cook's widow, Mrs Elizabeth Cook and her descendants until 1886. In this year Mr John Mackrell, the great nephew of [[Isaac Smith (Royal Navy officer)]], Elizabeth Cook's cousin, organized the display of this collection at the request of the NSW Government at the [[Colonial and Indian Exhibition]] in [[London]]. In 1887 the London-based [[Agent-General]] for the New South Wales Government, Saul Samuel, bought John Mackrell's items and also acquired those items belonging to the other relatives Reverend Canon Frederick Bennett, Mrs Thomas Langton, H.M.C.Alexander and Mr William Adams. The collection remained with the Colonial Secretary of NSW until 1894, when it was transferred to the Australian Museum.<ref name="Thomsett, History of Acquisition">{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection, History of Acquisition|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=35&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum Narrative|publisher=Australian Museum}}</ref>
==James Cook== {{Main|James Cook}}
[[File:James Cook statue closeup 574.JPG|150px|thumb|Statue of Captain James Cook at Admiralty Arch, London]]
[[Captain (Royal Navy)|Captain]] '''James Cook''', [[Royal Society|FRS]], [[Royal Navy|RN]] (7 November 1728<ref group="NB">[[Old Style and New Style dates|Old style date]]: 27 October</ref> – 14 February 1779) was a British explorer, navigator and cartographer who ultimately rose to the rank of captain in the Royal Navy. Cook made detailed maps of [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] prior to making three voyages to the Pacific Ocean, during which he achieved the first European contact with the eastern coastline of Australia and the [[Hawaiian Islands]], as well as the first recorded [[circumnavigation]] of [[New Zealand]].
Cook joined the British [[merchant navy]] as a teenager and joined the Royal Navy in 1755. He saw action in the [[Seven Years' War]], and subsequently surveyed and mapped much of the entrance to the [[Saint Lawrence River]] during the siege of [[Quebec]]. This helped bring Cook to the attention of the [[Admiralty]] and [[Royal Society]]. This notice came at a crucial moment in both Cook's career and the direction of British overseas exploration, and led to his commission in 1768 as commander of [[HMS Endeavour|HM Bark ''Endeavour'']] for the first of three Pacific voyages.
In three voyages Cook sailed thousands of miles across largely uncharted areas of the globe. He mapped lands from New Zealand to Hawaii in the Pacific Ocean in greater detail and on a scale not previously achieved. As he progressed on his voyages of discovery he surveyed and named features, and recorded islands and coastlines on European maps for the first time. He displayed a combination of [[seamanship]], superior surveying and cartographic skills, physical courage and an ability to lead men in adverse conditions.
Cook was killed in Hawaii in a fight with [[Native Hawaiians|Hawaiians]] during his third exploratory voyage in the Pacific in 1779. He left a legacy of scientific and geographical knowledge which was to influence his successors well into the 20th century and numerous memorials worldwide have been dedicated to him. However, his role in opening areas of the Pacific to [[colonisation]] and its subsequent effects on indigenous peoples have been the subject of both political and scholarly debate.
==Provenance==
===Hawaii=== Captain Cook first visited the [[Hawaiian Islands]] on 18 January 1778 on his third voyage, and his ships spent three months there, mostly anchored off [[Kauai]] and [[Hawaii]]. Cook considered them his most important discovery for England, and named the group the Sandwich Islands after his patron [[Lord Sandwich]], [[First Lord of the Admiralty]].
The objects acquired reflect the fact that the Hawaiians initially treated Cook as a god and presented him with high status goods such as feathered capes, hats, ornaments and images. As this was a point of first contact between Europeans and Hawaiians, a thriving trade developed, and a large number of artefacts, mostly those that were carried or worn, were brought back to England. Hawaiian collections from Cook's voyages show in particular the extent and variation of Hawaiian featherwork at the time.
Cook's ships returned to Hawaii nearly a year later after exploring the northwest coast of [[Americas|America]], [[Alaska]] and Northeast Asia. They spent a few weeks without incident and departed only to return due to a problem with the ship. On 14 February 1779, Cook was killed on Hawaii due to an unfortunate misunderstanding.
The artifacts in the Australian Museum's Cook collection attributed to Hawaii include a feathered cloak, 4 feathered circlet ornaments, a foundation mat for a feather cloak, a woven cane helmet, a nose whistle, a shark's tooth ring, 3 miniature bone carved turtles, a shark's tooth knife and more than 20 cut pieces of barkcloth.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- Hawaii|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=45|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000104- Feather Cape.jpg|H000104- Feather cloak ([[ʻahuʻula]]) File:H000087-_Lei.jpg|H000087- [[Lei (garland)|Lei]] File:H000111- Shark's tooth knife.jpg|H000111- Shark's tooth knife File:H000114- Netting for feather cape.jpg|H000114- Netting for feather cloak File:H000141- Wicker helmet.jpg|H000141- Wicker helmet ([[mahiole]]) File:H000150- Shark's tooth ring.jpg|H000150- Shark's tooth ring File:H000151-001- Carved turtle figures.tif|H000151-001- Carved turtle figures </gallery>
===American north west coast=== Cook's ships left Hawaii on 2 February 1778 and set course for North America, which they sighted on 7 March. On 29 March they discovered [[Nootka Sound]]. The area had been claimed by the Spanish under [[Juan José Pérez Hernández]], 1774 and the English by [[Francis Drake|Sir Francis Drake]], 1579. Cook named the area [[King George Sound]]. The Resolution and Discovery spent about one month in the area while the ships were repaired and made ready for the expedition to find the northwest passage.
A great deal of trading was done and the largest number of objects collected from the NorthWest Coast is from Nootka Sound. Objects from other groups may have been collected in Nootka. Wooden Combs were characteristic and several were collected (see H000110).
The next stop was [[Prince William Sound]] and [[Cook Inlet]]. The ethnographic specimens collected are very mixed and include [[Tlingit people]] and [[Athabaskan]]. Cook noted that none of the people lived in the bay where they had anchored. Containers of various kinds were made of mountain sheep horn. They appear to be Athabaskan in style (see H000056).
In [[Unalaska]] or the [[Aleutian Islands]] Samwell recorded that the crew traded cloth from Hawaii and Tahiti with the locals for arrows and other articles. Only a few objects can be traced to the voyages of Cook. Small ivory birds, possibly gaming pieces, were probably collected in Unalaska (see H000151). A large number of weapons and fishing and hunting implements, as well as a few paddles and canoe models, were collected in the northern parts of America and Asia and are hard to provenance (see H000106 and H00122 and H000139).<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- North West Coast America|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=75&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> <gallery> File:H000056-Scoop.jpg|H000056-Scoop File:H000110- Comb.jpg|H000110- Comb File:H000122- Fish hook.jpg|H000122- Fish hook File:H000139- Bone harpoon.jpg|H000139- Bone harpoon File:H000106- Harpoon.jpg|H000106- Harpoon File:H000151- Harpoon head.jpg|H000151- Harpoon head </gallery>
===New Caledonia=== Cook visited [[New Caledonia]] for two weeks during his second voyage in 1774. Eight days were spent in the Balad area, where Cook participated in a ritual exchange of gifts. Not many artefacts were collected, and most of these were weapons, which the local people were happy to sell to the visitors.New Caledonian hardwood clubs were finely carved and highly polished. (H000147, H000148) Hodges depicts a spearthrower being worn as an ornament to a hat. The Australian Museum's collection includes 3 spearthrowers (one ornamented: H000119). 3 knitted bags for slingstones were collected and the Australian Museum holds one of these (H000115). The Australian Museum's collection also includes 2 combs (H000108,H000109).<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- New Calidonia|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=72&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000108- Comb of quills.jpg|H000108- Comb of quills File:H000109- Comb of quills.jpg|H000109- Comb of quills File:H000115-Knitted Bark String Bag.jpg|H000115-Knitted Bark String Bag File:H000119-Carved Ornament.jpg|H000119-Carved Ornament File:H000147- Wooden club.jpg|H000147- Wooden club File:H000148- Wooden club.jpg|H000148- Wooden club </gallery>
===New Zealand=== The only known European contact with [[New Zealand]] prior to Cook's voyages was a short and hostile interaction when [[Abel Tasman]] visited [[Golden Bay]] on the north west tip of the South Island in 1642. On 8 October 1769 [[HMS Endeavour]], after 2 months at sea, anchored in a bay on the eastern side of the North Island. This was a case of first contact, and Cook and his crew did not succeed in peaceful interactions with the local Māori group, so the ship left the area with Cook naming it Poverty Bay. However the Endeavour went on to circumnavigate both the North and South Islands and there was contact with many different [[Māori people|Māori]] groups and exchanges of goods were made.
New Zealand was visited by [[France|French]] ships in 1769 and 1772, and Cook's ships returned on both the 2nd (1773) and third (1777) voyages. Kaeppler suggests that the availability of iron tools and the influence of European ideas and desires for certain goods may have stimulated changes in artefact production over the period of interactions.
As this AM collection came via Cook's widow and is therefore probably personal to Cook himself, it cannot be identified to a specific voyage, area or date. Kaeppler documents the types of artefacts collected from New Zealand during Cook's voyages. Over 40 cloaks were collected (H000103), a large number of body ornaments (H000222, H000156,H000063), feather boxes and musical instruments. Many weapons of nearly every type were collected, but this Cook collection has only one of these, a stone patu (H000085). There are 3 stone adze blades (H000082,83,84) and two fish hooks (H000137, H000138). Kaeppler notes that food preparation equipment was seldom collected, perhaps because exchanges happened away from the villages, and between men.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- New Zealand|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=69&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000063- Ear ornament or Kuru.jpg|H000063- Ear ornament or Kuru File:H000082- Adze blade.jpg|H000082- Adze blade File:H000085- Stone club or patu onewa.jpg|H000085- Stone club or patu onewa File:H000103- Cloak of dyed flax.jpg|H000103- Cloak of dyed flax File:H000137- Fish hook.jpg|H000137- Fish hook File:H000138- Fish hook.jpg|H000138- Fish hook File:H000156- Ear ornament or tangiwai.jpg|H000156- Ear ornament or tangiwai File:H000222- Neck ornament.jpg|H000222- Neck ornament </gallery>
===Society Island=== The island of [[Tahiti]], the largest of the 14 [[Society Islands]], was where Cook had his first contact with [[Pacific Islanders]]. [[Samuel Wallis]] had visited Tahiti on [[HMS Dolphin]] in June–July 1767. A brisk trade developed, and large quantities of iron nails and spikes were exchanged for barkcloth, fish hooks, pearls,shells, adzes and other tools. The Frenchman [[Louis-Antoine de Bougainville]] also visited in 1768, and the artefacts and stories brought back to Europe from these 2 voyages helped to create the vision of Tahiti as a south pacific paradise.
The Royal Society chose Tahiti as a suitable place to observe the [[astronomical]] event of the [[Transit of Venus]], and for this purpose Cook was sent on his first voyage. On 13 April 1769, after eight months at sea, the Endeavour arrived at Tahiti's [[Matavai Bay]], the same inlet that the Dolphin had visited 2 years before (4 men from the Dolphin had joined Cook's crew). The islanders welcomed Cook and Banks with green banana branches, calling them TAIO or friend, and giving them gifts of perfumed cloth. Soon afterwards a procession of canoes entered the bay and 'Queen' [[Purea]] presented Cook with a pig and fresh food,which was reciprocated by Cook with beads and trinkets.
The nearby promontory which Cook named [[Point Venus]] was used to observe the Transit of the planet Venus across the face of the Sun on 3 June 1769. Although this phenomenon was observed at 26 different points around the world, astronomers later realised that the telescopes of the day weren't precise enough to accomplish the task of accurately determining the distance between the Earth and the Sun.
Cook and Banks later circumnavigated the island of Tahiti and then visited the [[Bora Bora]] group, guided by a Tahitian priest [[Tupaia (navigator)]], who with his servant travelled on the Endeavour to Batavia, where he unfortunately became ill and died.
The Endeavour spent 3 months altogether in the Society Islands, and Cook's ships were to return 3 more times during later voyages (Aug-Sep1773, April-May1774,and Aug-Sep1777). During these visits there was a constant exchange of goods and gifts. Iron nails and axes were valued, and provisions, fish hooks, [[adzes]] and barkcloth were exchanged for these. A large number of objects were therefore collected, and many detailed drawings and maps of the islands were produced.
The items collected cannot be identified to a particular island or voyage, and before Cook arrived there had been a flourishing exchange of artefacts and ideas between the islands. Banks enjoyed the opportunities to witness and sometimes participate in Tahitian life. He took part in a HEIVA public dance ceremony, accompanied by drums and nose flute (seeH000143). He was also allowed to take part in a mourning ceremony and was fascinated by the costume worn by the chief mourner. According to Forster none of these were collected until the 2nd voyage, when parts of at least 10 were taken to England. Tha Australian Museum's collection has an example of the shell breast ornament component (see H000149). Semicircular breast ornaments, or gorgets, were commonly worn, and many were collected by the crew and valued as a special type of artificial curiosity (see H000105 and H000145). Barkcloth was presented in large pieces on several occasions to the visitors. Much of the cloth collected was cut into pieces and placed in books of barkcloth samples.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- Society Island|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=70&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000101- Bark cloth.jpg|H000101- Bark cloth File:H000105- Breast Ornament.jpg|H000105- Breast Ornament File:H000130- Fish hook.jpg|H000130- Fish hook File:H000133- Fish hook.jpg|H000133- Fish hook File:H000135- Fish hook.jpg|H000135- Fish hook File:H000136- Fish hook.jpg|H000136- Fish hook File:H000140- Fish hook.jpg|H000140- Fish hook File:H000143- Nose flute.jpg|H000143- Nose flute File:H000145- Breast ornament.jpg|H000145- Breast ornament File:H000149- Chest ornament.jpg|H000149- Chest ornament File:H000153- Wooden net needle.jpg|H000153- Wooden net needle File:H000212- Bark cloth.jpg|H000212- Bark cloth File:H000218- Bark cloth.jpg|H000218- Bark cloth </gallery>
===Tonga=== The [[Tonga]]n islands were visited by Le Maire in 1616, and Abel Tasman in 1643, but there are no identified Tongan artefacts collected from these voyages. The northern islands were sighted by the Englishman Samuel Wallis in 1767, and Cook's ships visited the islands for a few days in 1773 and then again briefly in June1774. He named them the Friendly Islands and returned on his third voyage in April–July 1777. It was known that Wallis had traded iron nails for a club in 1767, and the iron tools traded during Cook's second voyage stimulated different carving techniques which are evident in wooden artefacts collected on the third voyage.
Many specimens were collected from Tonga and many are specific to a particular voyage. Some items collected were of [[Fiji]]an and [[Samoa]]n origin, and this fact documents the pre-existing trade the Tongans had with their neighbours. Many body ornaments were collected, such as H000151- a small ivory human figure, probably strung on cord and worn as a neck ornament, and 3 shell necklaces H000116, H000117, H000152. Several kinds of [[pandanus]] mats were collected (H000098), as were many baskets of different styles and materials (H000102, a KATO MOSI KAKA beaded basket). Fly whisks, food preparation equipment, bowls, neckrests, noseflutes, panpipes, and various tools were collected, but the Australian Museum collection does not include examples of these. Some fishing equipment is present - a fish net H000144, and 11 fish hooks H000121- H000134. Combs collected were made from the midribs of coconut leaflets, intertwined with fine sennit cord to make decorative patterns.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- Tonga|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=71&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000098- Woven mat.jpg|H000098- Woven mat File:H000102- Basket.jpg|H000102- Basket File:H000116- Neck ornament.jpg|H000116- Neck ornament File:H000117- Neck ornament.jpg|H000117- Neck ornament File:H000121- Fish hook.jpg|H000121- Fish hook File:H000128- Fish hook.jpg|H000128- Fish hook File:H000144- Fishing net.jpg|H000144- Fishing net File:H000151- Carved Figure.jpg|H000151- Carved Figure File:H000152- Neck ornament.jpg|H000152- Neck ornament File:H000351- Comb.jpg|H000351- Comb </gallery>
===Vanuatu=== Quiros had named the islands of [[Vanuatu]] Australia Del Espiritu Santo, and Bougainville had visited in 1768. Cook made three landings on his second voyage on the islands of [[Malakula]], [[Erromango]], and [[Tanna (island)|Tanna]], and renamed the group the [[New Hebrides]]. There was open warfare, except for Tanna, so it is likely that all the non-weapons in Cook collections came from Tanna. [[Pan flute|Panpipes]] (H000112) in the AM collection have been attributed to Tanna. The arrows H000158-H000170 have also been attributed to Vanuatu. There are three clubs in the Banks collection that may possibly have been collected on Cook's second voyage - H000292-H000295, H000366 - can be compared to those in the Forster collection in Göttingen.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomsett|first=Sue|title=Cook Collection- Vanuatu|url=http://collections.australianmuseum.net.au/amweb/pages/am/NarrativeDisplay.php?irn=73&QueryPage=./NarrativeQuery.php|work=Electronic Museum|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
<gallery> File:H000112- Pan Pipes.jpg|H000112- Pan Pipes File:H000292- Club.jpg|H000292- Club File:H000158-164- Arrow heads.jpg|H000158-164- Arrow heads File:H000293- Club.jpg|H000293- Club File:H000295- Club.jpg|H000295- Club File:H000366- Club.jpg|H000366- Club </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
*[[Adrienne L. Kaeppler]] "Artificial Curiosities". Being an Exposition of Native Manufactures Collected on the Three Pacific Voyages of Captain James Cook, R. N. Honolulu, [[Bishop Museum]], 1978.
== Notes == {{Reflist|group=NB}}
{{authority control}}
