In addition, [[Hurricane Jimena (2003)|Hurricane Jimena]] of [[2003 Pacific hurricane season|2003]] is recognized per [[National Hurricane Center|NHC]], [[Central Pacific Hurricane Center|CPHC]] and [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center|JTWC]] as a storm that existed in all three areas of responsibility, but isn't recognized by the [[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]] as an official western Pacific tropical cyclone.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003jimena.shtml?|author=Richard B. Pasch|date=2003-12-18|title=Tropical Cyclone Report Hurricane Jimena|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-25}}{{cite web|author=Central Pacific Hurricane Center|accessdate=August 15, 2016|title=CPHC Rebest 1966-2003|url=ftp://eclipse.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/ibtracs/original-bt-data-files/cphc/CPHC_Rebest_1966-2003-1.xls|format=[[Microsoft Excel file format|XLS]]}}{{cite web|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|accessdate=August 15, 2016|title=JMA Best Track Data|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/jma-eng/jma-center/rsmc-hp-pub-eg/besttrack.html|format=[[Text file|TXT]]}} ===From Western Pacific to Central Pacific=== [[File:Hurricane John 23 aug 1994 1739Z.jpg|thumb|upright|1994's [[Hurricane John (1994)|Hurricane John]] crossed the dateline twice, from the central to the western Pacific and back]] Tropical cyclones crossing from the western Pacific to the central Pacific are fairly rare, and this has happened only seven times before. Of those seven times, five of them were storms which crossed the dateline twice; from the western to the central pacific and back (or vice versa). No tropical cyclone from the western Pacific has ever traveled east of 140°W. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" | Name ! scope="col" | Season ! scope="col" | {{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- ! In addition, [[1958 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane June|Typhoon June]] of [[1958 Pacific hurricane season|1958]] and [[2000 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Wene|Tropical Storm Wene]] of [[2000 Pacific hurricane season|2000]] are recognized per [[Central Pacific Hurricane Center|CPHC]] as basin-crossing storms, but aren't recognized as such by the [[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]].{{cite report|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS/IPS-D7B18921-B3C3-4E58-B2D5-1D63D3981DAE.pdf|format=pdf|title=CLIMATOLOGICAL DATA NATIONAL SUMMARY|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|publisher=U.S. Department of Commerce|accessdate=2015-08-19|location=United States of America}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite report|url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/cphc/summaries/2000.php|title=The 2000 Central Pacific Tropical Cyclone Season|author=Central Pacific Hurricane Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=2015-07-19|location=United States of America}} Also, [[1984 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Moke|Tropical Storm Moke]] of [[1984 Pacific hurricane season|1984]] may have achieved this feat as well, however it isn't recognized as an official western Pacific tropical cyclone by either the [[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]] or the [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center|JTWC]]. ===From Central Pacific to Eastern Pacific=== [[File:Tracks of Central-East Pacific crossover storms.png|thumb|Tracks of tropical cyclones that crossed from the central Pacific to the eastern Pacific]] Tropical cyclones crossing from the eastern Pacific to the central Pacific are routine; ones going the other way are not. That event has happened thrice. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" | Name ! scope="col" | Season ! scope="col" | {{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- ! scope="row" | [[1982 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ema|Ema]] | [[1982 Pacific hurricane season|1982]] | |- ! scope="row" | [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Olaf|Olaf]]{{dagger}} | [[2015 Pacific hurricane season|2015]] | {{cite web|last1=Kodama|first1=Forecaster|title=Tropical Storm Olaf Discussion 48|url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/cphc/tcpages/archive/2015/TCDCP5.EP192015.048.201510262055|website=Central Pacific Hurricane Center - Honolulu, Hawaii|publisher=Central Pacific Hurricane Center - Honolulu, Hawaii|accessdate=27 October 2015}} |- ! scope="row" | [[2016 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Ulika|Ulika]]{{dagger}} | [[2016 Pacific hurricane season|2016]] | {{cite web|last1=Jelsema|first1=Forecaster|title=TROPICAL STORM ULIKA ADVISORY NUMBER 5|url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/cphc/tcpages/archive/?prod=TCPCP2.EP192016.005.201609271723|website=Central Pacific Hurricane Center - Honolulu, Hawaii|publisher=Central Pacific Hurricane Center - Honolulu, Hawaii|accessdate=27 September 2016}} |} {{dagger}} System crossed 140°W more than once. It was previously believed that an [[Unnamed Hurricane (1975)|Unnamed Hurricane]] of [[1975 Pacific hurricane season|1975]] crossed 140°W and is still included in the [[National Hurricane Center|NHC]] as such, but according to a reanalysis made by the [[Central Pacific Hurricane Center|CPHC]] the storm became extratropical before doing so. In addition, an [[2006 central Pacific cyclone|unofficial cyclone]] formed on October 30, 2006 in the central Pacific subtropics. It eventually developed an [[eye (cyclone)|eye-like]] structure.{{cite web | publisher = [[NASA]] | title = Subtropical Storm off the Coast of Oregon | date = November 2, 2006 | accessdate = 2007-12-11 | url = http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/natural_hazards_v2.php3?img_id=13951 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5wfdFHGPB?url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/natural_hazards_v2.php3?img_id=13951 | archivedate = February 21, 2011 | df = }} Its track data indicates that it crossed from the central to the east Pacific because it formed at longitude 149°W and dissipated at 135°W.{{cite web|url=http://australiasevereweather.com/cyclones/2007/trak0611.htm|title=Global Tropical Cyclone Tracks - November 2006|author1=Gary Padgett |author2=Karl Hoarau |lastauthoramp=yes|accessdate=2007-12-28}} [[NASA]], which is not a meteorological organization, called this system a [[subtropical cyclone]], and the Naval Research Laboratory Monterey had enough interest in it to call it 91C. The system has also been called [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]].{{cite web|url=http://www.atl.ec.gc.ca/weather/hurricane/storm06.html |title=2006 Atlantic Hurricane Season Review |publisher=[[Canadian Hurricane Center]] |accessdate=2007-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070726014055/http://www.atl.ec.gc.ca/weather/hurricane/storm06.html |archivedate=2007-07-26 |df= }} This cyclone is unofficial because it is not included in the seasonal reports of either [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Center]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2006epac.shtml|title=2006 Eastern Pacific Hurricane Season|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-28}} ==Intensity records== ===Ten most intense=== [[File:Patricia 2015-10-23 1730Z (Worldview).jpg|thumb|right|[[Hurricane Patricia]], the most intense Pacific hurricane on record]] ====Per lowest central pressure==== The apparent increase in recent seasons is spurious; it is due to better estimation and measurement, not an increase in intense storms. That is, until 1988, Pacific hurricanes generally did not have their central pressures measured or estimated from satellite imagery. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" | Rank ! scope="col" | Hurricane ! virtue of its being the only known system. ==Unusual landfall locations== === California === {{See also|List of California hurricanes}} * '''After October or before June, 1854''' – A system considered a tropical cyclone makes landfall just north of the [[Golden Gate]]. * '''Late September, early October 1858''' – A [[1858 San Diego hurricane|hurricane]] makes a direct hit on Southern California before dissipating. [[San Diego]] experienced hurricane-force winds with torrential rainfall recorded all across Southern California. * '''After October or before June, 1859''' – A system considered a tropical cyclone makes landfall between [[Cape Mendocino]] and [[San Francisco Bay]]. * '''September 25, 1939''' – The [[1939 California tropical storm]] makes landfall in California, killing 45{{cite web|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|author=Willis E. Hurd|title=North Pacific Ocean, 1939|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|format=PDF|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/067/mwr-067-09-0356.pdf|pages=357–8|date=September 1939|accessdate=2007-12-13}} to 93.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|date=February 2010|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|format=PDF|pages=14|accessdate=22 January 2016}} * '''{{date|1972-09-06|mdy}}''' – [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Hyacinth|Tropical Depression Hyacinth]] makes landfall.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1972/HYACINTH/track.gif|title=Hurricane HYACINTH|format=GIF|publisher=Unisys|accessdate=2007-12-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103234848/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1972/HYACINTH/track.gif#|archive-date=2007-01-03|dead-url=yes|df=}} * '''{{date|1978-09-06|mdy}}''' – [[Hurricane Norman (1978)|Tropical Depression Norman]] makes landfall.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1978/NORMAN/track.gif|title=Hurricane NORMAN|publisher=Unisys|format=GIF|accessdate=2007-12-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102115718/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1978/NORMAN/track.gif#|archive-date=2007-01-02|dead-url=yes|df=}} === Hawaii === {{See also|List of Hawaii hurricanes}} [[File:Iniki 1992-09-11 2331.png|thumb|Hurricane Iniki over [[Hawaii]]]] * '''{{date|1871-08-09|mdy}}''' - Indigenous sources suggest that a Category 3 hurricane struck the Big Island and [[Maui]].{{cite journal |last = Businger |first = Steven |author2 = M. scope="row" | 9 | 570.0 || 22.44 || [[2001 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Flossie|Flossie 2001]] || Suchixtlahuaca, Mexico || |- ! scope="row" | 10 | 566.9 || 22.32 || [[1999 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Greg|Greg 1999]] || Tecoman, Mexico || |} ==Worldwide cyclone records set by Pacific storms== * '''Highest official wind speed ever recorded in a tropical cyclone''': [[Hurricane Patricia]] with maximum sustained winds of 215 mph (345 km/h).{{cite report|author=Richard J. Pasch|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=October 23, 2015|accessdate=October 23, 2015|title=Hurricane Patricia Discussion Number 14|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2015/ep20/ep202015.discus.014.shtml|location=Miami, Florida}} * '''Fastest intensification (1-minute sustained surface [[wind]]s)''': [[Hurricane Patricia]] 55 [[Metre per second|m/s]] (120 mph, 105 [[Knot (unit)|kt]], 195 km/h), from 40 [[Metre per second|m/s]] (85 mph, 75 [[Knot (unit)|kt]], 140 km/h) to 95 [[Metre per second|m/s]] (205 mph, 180 [[Knot (unit)|kt]], 335 km/h) in under 24 h{{cite report|author1=Todd B. Kimberlain |author2=Eric S. Blake |author3=John P. Cangialosi |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=February 1, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016|title=Hurricane Patricia|series=Tropical Cyclone Report|url={{NHC TCR url|id=EP202015_Patricia}}|format=PDF|location=Miami, Florida}} * '''Longest-lived tropical cyclone''': [[Hurricane John (1994)|Hurricane John]] lasted for 30 days and 18 hours. * '''Farthest-travelling tropical cyclone''': [[Hurricane John (1994)|Hurricane John]] travelled for 13,280 km. * '''Highest [[Accumulated cyclone energy|Accumulated cyclone energy (ACE)]] index for a tropical cyclone''': [[Hurricane Ioke|Hurricane/Typhoon Ioke]] achieved an ACE index of 82.{{cite web|author=Mark Saunders, Adam Lea |year=2007 |title=Summary of 2006 NW Pacific Typhoon Season and Verification of Authors’ Seasonal Forecasts |publisher=Tropical Storm Risk |accessdate=2007-10-11 |url=http://tsr.mssl.ucl.ac.uk/docs/TSRNWP2006Verification.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071129132910/http://tsr.mssl.ucl.ac.uk/docs/TSRNWP2006Verification.pdf |archivedate=2007-11-29 |df= }} * '''Tropical cyclone at Category 4 or 5 intensity on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Saffir-Simpson Scale]] for the longest''': [[Hurricane Ioke]] was at that intensity for 198 consecutive hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/cphc/summaries/2006.php|title=The 2006 Central Pacific Tropical Cyclone Season|publisher=Central Pacific Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-11-28}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[List of Atlantic hurricane records]] * [[List of Pacific hurricane seasons]] * [[List of tropical cyclones]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Pacific Hurricanes}} [[Category:Pacific hurricanes| Pacific hurricanes]] [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones|Pacific hurricanes]]

added [[Category:Ecoregions of Yemen]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The following is a list of [[ecoregion]]s in [[Yemen]], as identified by the [[Worldwide Fund for Nature]] (WWF).
==Terrestrial ecoregions== Yemen lies on the boundary between two of the world's terrestrial [[ecozone]]s. The [[Afrotropic]] ecozone covers the mountainous southern and eastern fringe of the Arabian Peninsula as well as [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] and [[Madagascar]]. The [[Palearctic]] ecozone covers the rest of the Arabian Peninsula as well as temperate [[Eurasia]] and [[Northern Africa]].
===[[Deserts and xeric shrublands]]===
* [[Arabian Desert|Arabian Desert and East Sahero-Arabian xeric shrublands]] (Palearctic) * [[Arabian Peninsula coastal fog desert]] (Afrotropic) * [[Red Sea Nubo-Sindian tropical desert and semi-desert]] (Palearctic) * [[Socotra]] Island xeric shrublands (Afrotropic) * [[Southwestern Arabian foothills savanna]] (Afrotropic) * [[Southwestern Arabian montane woodlands]] (Afrotropic)
==Marine ecoregions== * [[Southern Red Sea]] * [[Gulf of Aden]] * [[Western Arabian Sea]]
==References== * Burgess, Neil, Jennifer D’Amico Hales, Emma Underwood (2004). ''Terrestrial Ecoregions of Africa and Madagascar: A Conservation Assessment''. Island Press, Washington DC. * Spalding, Mark D., Helen E. Fox, Gerald R. Allen, Nick Davidson ''et al.'' "Marine Ecoregions of the World: A Bioregionalization of Coastal and Shelf Areas". ''Bioscience'' Vol. 57 No. 7, July/August 2007, pp. 573-583.
[[Category:Geography of Yemen]] [[Category:Environment of Yemen]] [[Category:Lists of ecoregions by country|Yemen]] [[Category:Yemen geography-related lists|Ecoregions]] [[Category:Flora of Yemen| ]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Yemen| ]]

page.title: List of flora and fauna named after the Muisca

revision.text:
{{Muisca sidebar}} [[File:Saguamachica2.jpg|thumb|right|170px|'''Saguamanchica''' was ''[[zipa]]'' of [[Bacatá]] between 1470 and 1490]] [[File:La Bachue de Jose Horacio Betancur-Medellin.JPG|thumb|right|170px|'''Bachué''' was the mother goddess of the Muisca]] [[File:Paramo zumapas.jpg|thumb|right|170px|'''Sumapaz Páramo''', to the south of Muisca territories, is the largest [[páramo]] in the world]] [[File:Represa del Sisga 01.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Landscape around '''Chocontá''']] [[File:Guasca vista desde el occidente.jpg|thumb|right|170px|The village of '''Guasca''' is close to Chingaza National Park]] [[File:Boyaca Topographic 2.png|thumb|right|170px|In '''Boyacá''', northern part of the Muisca Confederation, many species have been found and named]] The [[Muisca Confederation|Muisca]] were a people living in the central highlands of [[Colombia]]; the [[Altiplano Cundiboyacense]] and neighbouring valleys. The variation of climates and ecozones within their territories made the Muisca excellent [[Muisca agriculture|farmers]]. Over time, various species of flora and fauna have been discovered in Colombia. This list contains the living genera and species and fossils named after the Muisca, their [[Muisca religion|religion]] or their settlements. Three other Muisca etymologies are recognised; [[Thomagata Patera]], named after [[Muisca mythology|mythological ''cacique'']] [[Thomagata]], and [[Bochica Patera]] are volcanoes on [[Io (moon)|Io]] and [[BD Bacatá]] is the highest [[skyscraper]] of Colombia.[http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/5975 Thomagata Patera] - [[US Geological Survey|USGS]][http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/789?__fsk=-513521955 Bochica Patera] - [[US Geological Survey|USGS]][http://www.emporis.com/buildings/1180927/bd-bacata-torre-sur-bogota-colombia BD Bacatá at Emporis.com] == List of flora and fauna named after the Muisca == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! scope="col" | Name ! scope="col" | Gen/sp/fossil ! scope="col" | Type ! scope="col" | Named after ! scope="col" | Topic ! scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" class=unsortable | Notes |- | ''[[Muisca (genus)|Muisca]]'' | [[genus]] | [[checkered beetle|beetle]] | [[Muisca people|Muisca]] | people | align=center | | align=center | {{Cite web |url=http://bug.tamu.edu/research/collection/hallan/test/Arthropoda/Insects/Coleoptera/Family/Cleridae.txt# |title=''Muisca'' in the family of ''Clerinae'' or (disputed) ''Enopliinae'' |access-date=2016-07-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127035414/http://bug.tamu.edu/research/collection/hallan/test/Arthropoda/Insects/Coleoptera/Family/Cleridae.txt# |archive-date=2016-01-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} |- | ''[[Muisca bitaeniata]]'' | [[species]] | beetle | Muisca | people | align=center | [[File:1844 - revision.text:
{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{distinguish|List of most massive stars}} {{cite check|date=March 2018}} [[File:Star-sizes.jpg|500px|thumb|right|Relative sizes of the [[planets]] in the [[Solar System]] and several well-known [[stars]]: {{ordered list | [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] < [[Mars]] < [[Venus]] < [[Earth]] | [[Earth]] < [[Neptune]] < [[Uranus]] < [[Saturn]] < [[Jupiter]] | [[Jupiter]] < [[Proxima Centauri]] < [[Sun]] < [[Sirius A]] | [[Sirius A]] < [[Pollux (star)|Pollux]] < [[Arcturus]] < [[Aldebaran]] | [[Aldebaran]] < [[Rigel A]] < [[Antares A]] < [[Betelgeuse]] | [[Betelgeuse]] < [[Mu Cephei]] < [[VV Cephei A]] < [[VY Canis Majoris]] }} ]] Below is an ordered '''list of the largest stars''' currently known by [[radius]]. The unit of measurement used is the [[Solar radius|radius of the Sun]] (approximately {{convert|1|solar radius|km mi|0|abbr=on|disp=out|lk=on}}). The exact order of this list is very incomplete, as great uncertainties currently remain, especially when deriving various important parameters used in calculations, such as stellar [[luminosity]] and [[effective temperature]]. Often stellar radii can only be expressed as an average or within a large range of values. Values for stellar radii vary significantly in sources and throughout the literature, mostly as the boundary of the very tenuous atmosphere ([[Opacity (optics)|opacity]]) greatly differs depending on the wavelength of light in which the [[star]] is observed. Radii of several stars can be directly obtained by [[Astronomical optical interferometry|stellar interferometry]]. Other methods can use lunar [[occultation]]s or from [[eclipsing binaries]], which can be used to test other indirect methods of finding true stellar size. Only a few useful [[supergiant]] stars can be occulted by the Moon, including [[Antares]] and [[Aldebaran]]. Examples of eclipsing binaries include [[Epsilon Aurigae]], [[VV Cephei]], and [[HR 5171]]. __TOC__ ==Caveats== [[File:Sun and VY Canis Majoris.svg|thumb|right|309x309 px|The extreme [[red hypergiant]] star [[VY Canis Majoris]] compared to the Sun and Earth's orbit.]] Complex issues exist in determining the true radii of the largest stars, which in many cases do display significant errors. The following lists are generally based on various considerations or assumptions that include: * Largest stars are usually expressed in units of the [[solar radius]] ({{solar radius}}), where {{solar radius|1.00}} equals 695,700 kilometres. * Stellar radii or diameters are usually only approximated using [[Stefan–Boltzmann law]] for the deduced stellar [[luminosity]] and [[effective temperature|effective surface temperature]]; * [[Stellar distance]]s, and their errors, for most, remain uncertain or poorly determined; * Many supergiant stars have extended atmospheres and many are embedded within opaque dust shells, making their true effective temperatures highly uncertain; * Many extended supergiant atmospheres also significantly change in size over time, regularly or irregularly pulsating over several months or years as [[variable star]]s. This makes adopted [[luminosity|luminosities]] poorly known and may significantly change the quoted radii; * Other direct methods for determining stellar radii, rely on [[Occultation|lunar occultations]] or from eclipses in binary systems. This is only possible for a very small number of stars; * Based on various theoretical [[stellar evolution|evolutionary models]], few stars will exceed 1,500–2,000 times the Sun (roughly 3,715 K and Mbol = −9). Such limits maybe also depend on the stellar [[metallicity]]. ==Extragalactic large stars== In this list are some examples of more distant extragalactic stars, which may have slightly different properties and natures than the currently largest known stars in the [[Milky Way]]: * Some red [[supergiant]]s in the [[Magellanic Clouds]] are suspected to have slightly different limiting [[effective temperature|temperature]]s and [[bolometric luminosity|luminosities]]. Such stars may exceed accepted limits by undergoing large eruptions or change their [[spectral type]]s over just a few months. Humphreys ''et al.'', for example, calculates the maximum size for a Magellanic cloud star as {{solar radius|~2,600}}.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} * A survey of the [[Magellanic Clouds]] has catalogued many [[red supergiant]]s, where more than 50 of them exceed {{convert|700|solar radius|km AU mi|abbr=on|lk=on|}}. Largest of these is about 1,200–1,300 {{solar radius}}.{{Cite journal|title = The Effective Temperatures and Physical Properties of Magellanic Cloud Red Supergiants: The Effects of Metallicity|year = 2006 |last1 = Levesque | first1 = Emily M.|last2 = Massey | first2 = Philip|last3 = Olsen | first3 = K.A.G.|last4 = Plez | first4 = Bertrand |last5 = Meynet | first5 = Georges |last6 = Maeder | first6 = Andre|journal = The Astrophysical Journal |volume = 645 |issue = 2 |pages = 1102–1117 |arxiv = astro-ph/0603596 |bibcode = 2006ApJ...645.1102L|doi = 10.1086/504417}} {{clear}} ==List== {{Expand list|date=January 2016}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+'''List of the largest stars''' |- ! style="background:#efefef; white-space:nobr;" | Star name ! style="background:#ffdead;" | [[Solar radius|Solar radii]]
([[Sun]] = 1) ! Method{{efn|AD: radius determined from angular diameter and distance
L/Teff: radius calculated from [[bolometric luminosity]] and [[effective temperature]]}} ! Notes |-style="background:Gold;" class="sortbottom" | [[Orbit of Saturn]] || 1,940–2,169 || || Reported for reference |- |[[UY Scuti]] || 1,708 ± 192{{cite journal |title=The atmospheric structure and fundamental parameters of the red supergiants AH Scorpii, UY Scuti, and KW Sagittarii |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |volume=554 |issue=A76 |pages=A76 |date=June 2013 |bibcode=2013A&A...554A..76A |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201220920 |arxiv = 1305.6179 |last1=Arroyo-Torres |first1=B |last2=Wittkowski |first2=M |last3=Marcaide |first3=J. M |last4=Hauschildt |first4=P. H }} || AD || The quoted size was based on an angular diameter and distance of 2.9 [[kiloparsec|kpc]]. [[Gaia Data Release 2]] suggests a much closer distance and consequently smaller radius. |- | [[WOH G64]] || 1,540{{cite journal |title=The Physical Properties of the Red Supergiant WOH G64: The Largest Star Known? |journal=Astronomical Journal |volume=137 |issue=6 |page=4744 |date=June 2009 |bibcode=2009AJ....137.4744L |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/137/6/4744 |arxiv = 0903.2260 |last1=Levesque |first1=Emily M |last2=Massey |first2=Philip |last3=Plez |first3=Bertrand |last4=Olsen |first4=Knut A. Because the spectral type and temperature at maximum luminosity are not known, the quoted size is just an estimate. |- | [[Westerlund 1-26]] || {{nobr| 1,530–1,580{{cite journal|bibcode=2014MNRAS.437L...1W|arxiv=1309.4086|title=The ionized nebula surrounding the red supergiant W26 in Westerlund 1|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society: Letters|volume=437|issue=1|pages=L1|author1=Wright|first1=Nicholas J|last2=Wesson|first2=Roger|last3=Drew|first3=Janet E|last4=Barentsen|first4=Geert|last5=Barlow|first5=Michael J|last6=Walsh|first6=Jeremy R|last7=Zijlstra|first7=Albert|last8=Drake|first8=Jeremy J|last9=Eislöffel|first9=Jochen|last10=Farnhill|first10=Hywel J|year=2014|doi=10.1093/mnrasl/slt127}} (–2,550) }}{{Cite journal|arxiv=1209.6427|last1=Fok|first1=Thomas K. T|title=Maser Observations of Westerlund 1 and Comprehensive Considerations on Maser Properties of Red Supergiants Associated with Massive Clusters|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=760|pages=65|last2=Nakashima|first2=Jun-ichi|last3=Yung|first3=Bosco H. K|last4=Hsia|first4=Chih-Hao|last5=Deguchi|first5=Shuji|year=2012|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/760/1/65}} || L/Teff || Very uncertain parameters for an unusual star with strong radio emission. The spectrum is variable but apparently the luminosity is not. |- | [[HD 143183]] || 1,480{{Cite journal|doi=10.1086/378380|title=Really Cool Stars and the Star Formation History at the Galactic Center|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=597|pages=323–346|year=2003|last1=Blum|first1=R. |title=HIFISTARSHerschel/HIFI observations of VY Canis Majoris |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |volume=559 |pages=A93 |year=2013 |last1=Alcolea |first1=J |last2=Bujarrabal |first2=V |last3=Planesas M }} Other stars could be larger but they could have less accurate radius estimates. |- | [[KY Cygni]] || {{nobr| 1,420–2,850 }} || L/Teff || The upper estimate is due to an unusual [[K band (infrared)|K-band]] measurement and thought to be an artifact of a reddening correction error, and is thought to be against stellar evolutionary theory. The lower estimate is consistent with other stars in the same survey and with theoretical models. |- | [[AH Scorpii]] || {{nobr|1,411 ± 124}} || AD || AH Sco is variable by nearly 3 magnitudes in the visual range, and an estimated 20% in total luminosity. The variation in diameter is not clear because the temperature also varies. |- | [[RSGC1]]-F02 || 1,398 || L/Teff || |- | [[IRAS 04509-6922]] || 1,360 || L/Teff || |- | [[RSGC1]]-F01 || 1,335 || L/Teff || |- | [[V766 Centauri|HR 5171 A]] || {{nobr|1,315 ± 260}},{{cite journal |bibcode=2014A&A...563A..71C |arxiv=1401.2628v2 |title=The yellow hypergiant HR 5171 A: Resolving a massive interacting binary in the common envelope phase |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |volume=563 |pages=A71 |author1=Chesneau|first1=O. |last2=Meilland|first2=A. |last3=Chapellier|first3=E. |last4=Millour|first4=F. |last5=Van Genderen|first5=A. page.title: List of national parks of Denmark

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Denmark]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Location map many | Denmark | relief = yes | caption = National parks in Denmark ([[Northeast Greenland National Park]] not shown) | width = 350 | label = [[Thy National Park|Thy]] | bg = white | pos = left | coordinates = {{coord|56|57|N|8|27|E}} | label2 = [[Mols Bjerge National Park|Mols Bjerge]] | bg2 = white | coordinates2 = {{coord|56|14|N|10|36|E}} | label3 = [[Wadden Sea National Park, Denmark|Wadden Sea]] | bg3 = white | coordinates3 = {{coord|55|15|N|8|38|E}} | label4 = [[Land of the Scylding National Park|Land of the Scylding]] | bg4 = white | coordinates4 = {{coord|55|40|N|12|00|E}} | label5 = [[Kongernes Nordsjælland National Park|Kongernes Nordsjælland]] | bg5 = white | coordinates5 = {{coord|56|00|N|12|20|E}} }} There are six '''national parks in the [[Denmark|Kingdom of Denmark]]'''; five in Denmark proper and one in [[Greenland]]. The first national park in Denmark proper was [[Thy National Park]] ({{lang-da|Nationalpark Thy}}), created in 2008. It is located in [[Thisted Municipality]], [[Region Nordjylland|Nordjylland]]. The park is a narrow stretch of land along the [[North Jutlandic Island]]'s west coast from [[Hanstholm]] southward to [[Agger Tange]], excluding Hanstholm, Klitmøller, Nørre Vorupør, Stenbjerg and Agger. Thy National Park is named after [[Thy (district)|Thy]], an area that includes not only today's national park but also adjacent land further east. The park has dunes, [[Heath (habitat)|heath]], forests and grassland and also covers several small lakes and a small part of the [[Limfjord]], which is the fjord that separates the North Jutlandic Island from the [[Jutland Peninsula|Cimbrian Peninsula]]. In August 2009, the second national park [[Mols Bjerge National Park]] was inaugurated, followed by [[Wadden Sea National Park, Denmark|Wadden Sea National Park]] in October 2010,http://www.mim.dk/Nyheder/Pressemeddelelser/20101016_Indvielse_af_Nationalpark_Vadehavet.htm{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and [[Land of the Scylding National Park]] in 2015. Two additional areas in mainland Denmark were proposed in 2008 and 2009 to become national parks, but one of these plans was abandoned in 2012. The other, [[Kongernes Nordsjælland National Park]], was inaugurated in 2018.{{cite web |date=24 March 2018 |title=Kongernes Nordsjælland |url=http://danmarksnationalparker.dk/kongernes-nordsjaelland/ | publisher=Danmarks Nationalparker | accessdate=29 May 2018}} Greenland has had its own national park since 1974. The [[Northeast Greenland National Park]] stretches across three fifths of the northern parts of [[Greenland]]'s east coast and, since its expansion in 1988, two thirds of the eastern parts of Greenland's north coast. Bounded by the coasts, the park covers the island's entire north-eastern quarter, all of which is almost uninhabited.[http://www.natur.gl/filer/biodiversity_greenland/Map14.pdf map of Greenland's protected areas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051004015514/http://www.natur.gl/filer/biodiversity_greenland/Map14.pdf |date=2005-10-04 }} Like Greenland, the [[Faroe Islands]] forms another [[Autonomous administrative division|autonomous region]] of the Kingdom of Denmark, but contains no national parks. {| class="sortable wikitable" width="70%" |+ List of national parks in the Kingdom of Denmark |- ! Image ! Name ! [[Danish language|Danish]] name ! [[Regions of Denmark|Region]] ! Area in km² ! Establishment ! External link |- | [[Image:Franz Josef Fjord, glacier.jpg|150px]] | [[Northeast Greenland National Park]] {{#tag:ref|Official English name unknown. A [[World Conservation Monitoring Centre|WCMC]] web page uses “North-east Greenland National Park”. [http://sea.unep-wcmc.org/sites/pa/0352v.htm]|group=note}} | ''Grønlands Nationalpark'' | Northeast [[Greenland]] | 972,000 | 1974 | — |- | [[Image:Nørre Vorupør Coast 2012-11-18.jpg|150px]] | [[Thy National Park]] | ''Nationalpark Thy'' | [[Region Nordjylland|Nordjylland]] | 243.7 | 2008 | [http://danmarksnationalparker.dk/english/thy/ SNS] |- | [[Image:Trehoje i Mols Bjerge.jpg|150px]] | [[Mols Bjerge National Park]]
(''Mols Mountains'') | ''Nationalpark Mols Bjerge'' | [[Region Midtjylland|Midtjylland]] | 180 {{#tag:ref|About 150 km² land and about 30 km² sea.|group=note}} | 2009 | [http://eng.nationalparkmolsbjerge.dk/ SNS] |- | [[Image:Vadehavet.jpg|150px]] | [[Wadden Sea National Park, Denmark|Wadden Sea National Park]] | ''Nationalpark Vadehavet'' | [[Region of Southern Denmark|Southern Denmark]] | 1,466 | 2010 | [http://danmarksnationalparker.dk/english/waddensea/ SNS] |- | [[File:Boserup Skov, Roskilde.jpg|150px|]] | [[Land of the Scylding National Park]]
(''Land of the Scylding'') | ''Nationalpark Skjoldungernes Land'' | [[Region Sjælland|Zealand]] | 170[http://nationalparkskjoldungernesland.dk/om-nationalpark-skjoldungernes-land/ Om Nationalpark Skjoldungernes Land] | 2015 | [http://nationalparkskjoldungernesland.dk/ SNS] (Danish) |- | [[File:Grib skov.jpg|150px]] | [[Kongernes Nordsjælland National Park]] | ''Nationalpark Kongernes Nordsjælland'' | [[Region Hovedstaden|Hovedstaden]] | 262.5 | {{sort|2018|2018}}Avisen.dk (15 December 2017). [https://www.avisen.dk/advertorials/ritzauinfo/nationalpark-kongernes-nordsjaelland-bliver-nu-til-v_475980.aspx Nationalpark Kongernes Nordsjælland bliver nu til virkelighed]. | [http://www.kongernes-nordsjælland.dk SNS] (Danish) |- | | Skjern Å National Park (''Skjern River'') | ''Nationalpark Skjern Å'' | [[Region Midtjylland|Midtjylland]] | 248.7 | {{sort|2008-12|(never established and project abandoned 2012)}}Kristeligt Dagblad (23 March 2012). [https://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/danmark/nationalpark-skjern-å-er-opgivet Nationalpark Skjern Å er opgivet]. | [https://web.archive.org/web/20170302163848/http://danmarksnationalparker.dk/organisation/historien-bag/skjern-%c3%a5/ SNS] (Danish) |} ==Footnotes== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|group=note}} '''References''' {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://danmarksnationalparker.dk/english/ Danish Forest and Nature Agency's website on the national parks of mainland Denmark] * ''[http://www.nanoq.gl/sitecore/content/Websites/nanoq/Emner/Landsstyre/Departementer/Departement_for_indenrigsanliggender/Milj%C3%B8styrelsen.aspx Avatangiisinut Pinngortitamullu Aqutsisoqarfik]'' (Greenlandic) = ''[http://dk.nanoq.gl/sitecore/content/Websites/nanoq/Emner/Landsstyre/Departementer/Departement_for_indenrigsanliggender/Milj%C3%B8styrelsen.aspx Miljø- og Naturstyrelsen]'' (Danish).
Operates under [http://uk.nanoq.gl/ Greenland Home Rule]'s new ministry for domestic affairs ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090816152835/http://www.nanoq.gl/Emner/Landsstyre/Departementer/Departement_for_indenrigsanliggender.aspx Greenlandic] · [https://web.archive.org/web/20090723005324/http://dk.nanoq.gl/Emner/Landsstyre/Departementer/Departement_for_indenrigsanliggender.aspx Danish]) * Faroese [https://web.archive.org/web/20140110132841/http://imr.fo/ Ministry of the Interior] (Faroese) {{National parks of Denmark}} {{Europe in topic|List of national parks of|countries_only=yes}} [[Category:National parks of Denmark| ]] [[Category:National parks in Greenland| ]] [[Category:Lists of national parks|Denmark]] [[Category:Denmark geography-related lists|National parks]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Denmark|National parks]]

{{Commons category|Rivers of Sierra Leone}}
This is a '''list of rivers in [[Sierra Leone]]'''. This list is arranged by drainage basin, with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name.
==[[Atlantic Ocean]]==
*[[Great Scarcies River]] (Kolenté River) *[[Little Scarcies River]] (Kaba River) **[[Mabole River]] **[[Mongo River (Little Scarcies River)|Mongo River]] **[[Lolo River (Little Scarcies River)|Lolo River]] *[[Sierra Leone River]] **[[Rokel River]] (Seli River) **[[Bankasoka River]] (called ''Port Loko Creek'' in the tidal part) *[[Ribi River]] *[[Bumpe River]] *[[Kagboro Creek]] *[[Sherbro River]] **[[Bagru River]] **[[Jong River]] (Taia River) ***[[Pampana River]] ***[[Teye River]] *[[Kittam River]] **[[Sewa River]] ***[[Bagbe River]] ***[[Bafi River]] **[[Waanje River]] *[[Moa River]] **[[Meli River]] *[[Mano River]] **[[Mahoi River]] **[[Moro River (Mano River)|Moro River]]
==References== *Rand McNally, ''The New International Atlas'', 1993. *[http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/index.html GEOnet Names Server] *[https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/sierrale.pdf United Nations, Department for Peacekeeping Operations Cartographic Section, 2004]

page.title: Lists of forests of the Western Cape

revision.comment: /* List of Forests in the Western Cape, South Africa */
revision.text:
This is a '''list of [[forest]]s of the [[Western Cape]]''' province of [[South Africa]].
==List of Forests in the Western Cape, South Africa== These are generally examples of '''[[Southern Afrotemperate Forest]]''', the predominant indigenous forest-type in the Western Cape.
* [[Cecilia Forest]] * [[Grootvadersbosch]] * [[Kirstenbosch]] * [[Knysna Forest]] * [[Newlands Forest]] * [[Orangekloof Forest]] * [[Platbos]] * [[Knysna-Amatole montane forests|Knysna Forest]]
==See also==
* [[KwaZulu-Cape coastal forest mosaic]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Forests Of The Western Cape}} [[Category:Forests of South Africa]] [[Category:Geography of the Western Cape]] [[Category:Lists of forests of South Africa|Western Cape]] [[Category:Western Cape-related lists|Foresrs]]

revision.comment: /* Looming */
revision.text:
[[File:Illustration of looming refration phenomenon.jpg|300px|thumb|The distant boats appear to be floating in the sky as a result of looming and other refraction phenomena.]] While [[mirage]]s are the best known [[atmospheric refraction]] phenomena, '''looming and similar refraction phenomena''' do not produce mirages. Mirages show an extra image or images of the miraged object, while looming, towering, stooping, and sinking do not. No inverted image is present in those phenomena either. Depending on atmospheric conditions, the objects can appear to be elevated or lowered, stretched or stooped. These phenomena can occur together, changing the appearance of different parts of the objects in different ways. Sometimes these phenomena can occur together with a true mirage.<ref name="The Superior Mirage: Seeing Beyond">{{cite web|title=The Superior Mirage: Seeing Beyond|first=Keith|last=Heidorn|date=July 15, 1999|url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/elements/supmrge.htm|publisher=The Weather Doctor|accessdate=April 23, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Looming, Towering, Stooping, and Sinking">{{cite web|title=Looming, Towering, Stooping, and Sinking|first=Andrew|last=Young|url=http://mintaka.sdsu.edu/GF/mirages/mirsims/loom/loom.html|publisher=[[San Diego State University]]|accessdate=April 23, 2010}}</ref>
==Looming== [[Image:Rochester Mirage.jpg|Looming of the Canadian coast as seen from [[Rochester, New York]] on April 16th of 1871|thumb|left]] Looming is the most noticeable and most often observed of these refraction phenomena. It is an abnormally large refraction of the object that increases the apparent elevation of the distant objects and sometimes allows an observer to see objects that are located below the horizon under normal conditions. One of the most famous looming observations was made by [[William Latham, F.R.S.|William Latham]] in 1798, who wrote: {{Quotation|I could very plainly see the cliffs on the opposite coast; which, at the nearest part, are between forty and fifty miles distant, and are not to be discerned, from that low situation, by the aid of the best glasses. They appeared to be only a few miles off, and seemed to extend for some leagues along the coast.<ref name="William Latham">{{cite journal|first=William|last=Latham|title=Account of a Singular Instance of Atmospherical Refraction|year=1798|publisher=The Royal Society|jstor=106981|volume=88|pages=357–360|issn=0261-0523|oclc=486168582}}</ref>}}
[[Thomas Jefferson]] noted the phenomenon of looming in his book [[Notes on the State of Virginia]]:
{{Quotation|There is a solitary mountain about 40 miles off, in the South, whose natural shape as presented to view there, is a regular cone; but, by the effect of looming it sometimes subsides almost totally into the horizon; sometimes it rises more acute and more elevated, its top flat, and as broad as its base. In short it assumes at times the most whimsical shapes, and all these perhaps successively in the same morning.<ref>{{cite book|first=Thomas|last=Jefferson|title=Notes on the State of Virginia}}</ref>}}
He was unable to explain this phenomenon and did not think refraction could account from the perceived changes of shape of the object in question.
Other famous observations that were called "mirages" may actually be referring to looming. One of those was described in ''Scientific American'' on August 25, 1894 as "a remarkable mirage seen by the citizens of [[Buffalo, New York]]".<ref name="SciAm 1894">{{Cite journal|date=August 25, 1894|title=A mirage at Buffalo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YoA9AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA115|journal=Scientific American|volume=71|page=115|via=Google Books}} {{open access}}</ref><ref name="A MIRAGE SEEN AT BUFFALO">{{cite book|title=Miscellaneous notes and queries|publisher=S. C. and L. M. Gould|year=1894|volume=12|location=Manchester, New Hampshire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hywAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA314&lpg=PA314&dq=The+people+of+Buffalo,+N.+Y.,+were+treated+to+a+remarkable+mirage,+between+ten+and+eleven&source=web&ots=wQGQmHqTzo&sig=04_IMtSmzYgezni9dqB_oC7W1Mc&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result|page=314|oclc=448141550}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/11506169/lake_ontario_mirage/|title=Mirage seen: Toronto Bay and City brought close to Buffalo|date=August 16, 1894|work=The Buffalo Commercial|access-date=July 1, 2018|page=9|via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> Such looming—sometimes with apparent magnification of opposite shores—have been reported over the Great Lakes. Canadian shorelines have been observed from Rochester, New York across Lake Ontario, and from Cleveland across Lake Erie. The land forms over 50 miles distant, normally beyond the horizon, were sometimes perceived as 6 miles away.
Looming is most commonly seen in the [[polar region]]s. Looming was sometimes responsible for the errors made by polar explorers; for example, [[Charles Wilkes]] charted the coast of [[Antarctica]], where later only water was found.
The larger the size of the sphere (the planet where an observer is located) the less curved the horizon is. [[William Jackson Humphreys|William Jackson Humphreys']] calculations showed that an observer could see all the way around a planet nearly six times larger in radius than the Earth, with the same [[atmosphere]] as the Earth, because of looming.<ref name="Popular Mechanics">{{cite journal|title=Popular Mechanics|first=Calvin|last=Frazer|date=August 1929|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation|Hearst Magazines]]|issn=0032-4558|oclc=3643271|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y94DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA242&dq=%22atmospheric+refraction%22+looming&hl=en&ei=eWrQS7_FHoTYtgPDlvnUDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22atmospheric%20refraction%22%20looming&f=false|volume=52}}</ref>
==Sinking== Sinking is the opposite of looming. In sinking, stationary objects that are normally seen above the [[horizon]] appear to be lowered, or may even disappear below the horizon. In looming, the curvature of the rays is increasing, while sinking produces the opposite effect.<ref name="Physics of the air">{{cite book |first=William Jackson |last=Humphreys |title=Physics of the air |year=1920 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBUBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR10&lpg=PR10&dq=looming+towering+stooping&source=bl&ots=3HaAi3lY-q&sig=40ZDlGjMwwpll7QpqgY-M5znUiI&hl=en&ei=VBrCS92wJYWNnQeKxOjTDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CB0Q6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=looming&f=false |page=449 |oclc=569637}}</ref> In general, looming is more noticeable than sinking because objects that appear to grow stand out more than those that appear to shrink.
==Towering and stooping== Towering and stooping are more complex forms of [[atmospheric refraction]] than looming and sinking. While looming and sinking change the apparent elevation of an object, towering and stooping change the apparent shape of the object itself. With towering, objects appear stretched; with stooping, objects seem to be shortened. The apparent stretching and shortening of the objects are not symmetrical and depends on the [[thermal profiling|thermal profile]] of the atmosphere. The curvature of the rays changes more rapidly in some places because the thermal profile is curved.<ref name="Looming, Towering, Stooping, and Sinking"/><ref name="Physics of the air"/>
==Image example and explanation== [[File:Looming with towering and mirage of Farallon Islands.jpg|thumb|Three photos showing a looming, towering, and [[Fata Morgana (mirage)|Fata Morgana]] of the [[Farallon Islands]]]]
These three images were taken from the same place on different days under different atmospheric conditions. The top frame shows looming. The island shape is not distorted, but is elevated. The middle frame shows looming with towering. The lowest frame is a 5-image [[superior mirage]] of the islands. The uppermost image is stooped severely. As the image shows, the different refraction phenomena are not independent from each other and may occur together as a combination, depending on atmospheric conditions.<ref name="Looming, Towering, Stooping, and Sinking"/>
==See also== *[[Mirage of astronomical objects]] *[[Fata Morgana (mirage)]] *[[Tropospheric propagation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons|Mirage}} *[http://mintaka.sdsu.edu/GF/bibliog/bibliog.html Annotated Green-Flash and Mirage Bibliography by Andy Young]
[[Category:Atmospheric optical phenomena]]
