revision.text:
{{Essay-like|date=March 2013}} '''Macroscopic quantum phenomena''' refer to processes showing [[Quantum mechanics|quantum behavior]] at the [[macroscopic scale]], rather than at the [[Atom|atomic scale]] where quantum effects are prevalent. The best-known examples of macroscopic quantum phenomena are [[superfluidity]] and [[superconductivity]]; other examples include the [[quantum Hall effect]] and concerted [[proton tunneling]] in ice.{{cite journal|author1=Yen, F. |author2=Gao, T. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Dielectric Anomaly in Ice near 20 K; Evidence of Macroscopic Quantum Phenomena|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters|year=2015|volume=6|issue=14|pages=2822–2825|doi=10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b00797|pmid=26266868 |arxiv=1508.00215}} Since 2000 there has been extensive experimental work on quantum gases, particularly [[Bose–Einstein condensate|Bose–Einstein Condensates]]. Between 1996 and 2003 four [[Nobel Prize]]s were given for work related to macroscopic quantum phenomena.These [[List of Nobel laureates in Physics|Nobel prizes]] were for the discovery of super-fluidity in [[helium-3]] (1996), for the discovery of the [[fractional quantum Hall effect]] (1998), for the demonstration of [[Bose–Einstein condensation]] (2001), and for contributions to the theory of [[superconductivity]] and [[superfluidity]] (2003). Macroscopic quantum phenomena can be observed in atomic systems such as [[superfluid helium]] and in [[superconductors]],D.R. Tilley and J. Tilley, ''Superfluidity and Superconductivity'', Adam Hilger, Bristol and New York, 1990 but also in dilute quantum gases, [[dressed particle|dressed photons]] such as [[Bose–Einstein_condensation_of_polaritons|polaritons]] and in [[laser]] light. Although these media are very different, their behavior is very similar as they all show macroscopic quantum behavior and to such extent they all can be referred to as [[quantum fluid]]s. Quantum phenomena are generally classified as macroscopic when the quantum states are occupied by a large number of particles (typically [[Avogadro's number]]) or the quantum states involved are macroscopic in size (up to km size in [[superconducting]] wires).{{cite journal|last1=Jaeger|first1=Gregg|title=What in the (quantum) world is macroscopic?|journal=American Journal of Physics|date=September 2014|volume=82|issue=9|pages=896–905|doi=10.1119/1.4878358|bibcode = 2014AmJPh..82..896J }} ==Consequences of the macroscopic occupation== [[File:Particles in a box02.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig.1 Left: only one particle; usually the small box is empty. However, there is a certain chance that the particle is in the box. This chance is given by Eq.(15). Middle: a few particles. There are usually some particles in the box. We can define an average, but the actual number of particles in the box has large fluctuations around this average. Right: large number of particles. The fluctuations around the average are small.]] The concept of macroscopically-occupied quantum states is introduced by [[Fritz London]].Fritz London ''Superfluids'' (London, Wiley, 1954-1964){{Cite journal | last1 = Gavroglu | first1 = K. | last2 = Goudaroulis | first2 = Y. | doi = 10.1080/00033798800200291 | title = Understanding macroscopic quantum phenomena: The history of superfluidity 1941–1955 | journal = Annals of Science | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 367 | year = 1988 | pmid = | pmc = }} In this section it will be explained what it means if the ground state is occupied by a very large number of particles. We start with the wave function of the ground state written as :{| width=250px | \Psi = \Psi _0 \exp(i\varphi) | style="text-align:right"|(1) |} with ''Ψ''₀ the amplitude and \varphi the phase. The wave function is normalized so that :{| width=250px | \int \Psi \Psi ^* \mathrm{d}V = N_s. | style="text-align:right"|(2) |} The physical interpretation of the quantity :{| width=250px | \Psi \Psi ^* \Delta V | style="text-align:right"|(3) |} depends on the number of particles. Fig.1 represents a container with a certain number of particles with a small control volume Δ''V'' inside. We check from time to time how many particles are in the control box. We distinguish three cases: 1. There is only one particle. In this case the control volume is empty most of the time. However, there is a certain chance to find the particle in it given by Eq.(3). The chance is proportional to Δ''V''. The factor ''ΨΨ''∗ is called the chance density. 2. If the number of particles is a bit larger there are usually some particles inside the box. We can define an average, but the actual number of particles in the box has relatively large fluctuations around this average. 3. In the case of a very large number of particles there will always be a lot of particles in the small box. The number will fluctuate but the fluctuations around the average are relatively small. The average number is proportional to Δ''V'' and ''ΨΨ''∗ is now interpreted as the particle density. In quantum mechanics the particle probability flow density ''J''p (unit: particles per second per m²) can be derived from the [[Schrödinger equation]] to be :{| width=500px | \vec{J}_p = \frac{1}{2m}\left(\Psi (i \frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla} -q \vec{A})\Psi^* +cc \right) | style="text-align:right"|(4) |} with ''q'' the charge of the particle and \vec{A} the vector potential.{{dubious|date=April 2015}} With Eq.(1) :{| width=500px | \vec{J}_p = \frac {\Psi_0^2}{m}\left(\frac{h}{2 \pi} \vec{\nabla} \varphi - q \vec{A}\right). | style="text-align:right"|(5) |} If the wave function is macroscopically occupied the particle probability flow density becomes a particle flow density. We introduce the fluid velocity ''v''s via the mass flow density :{| width=500px | m\vec{J}_p=\rho _s \vec{v}_s. | style="text-align:right"|(6) |} The density (mass per m³) is :{| width=300px | m \Psi_0^2 = \rho_s | style="text-align:right"|(7) |} so Eq.(5) results in :{| width=300px | \vec{v}_s=\frac{1}{m}\left(\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla}\varphi-q\vec{A}\right). | style="text-align:right"|(8) |} This important relation connects the velocity, a classical concept, of the condensate with the phase of the wave function, a quantum-mechanical concept. ==Superfluidity== {{main|Superfluid}} [[File:Vortex lines in rotating helium01.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig.2 Lower part: vertical cross section of a column of superfluid helium rotating around a vertical axis. Upper part: Top view of the surface showing the pattern of vortex cores. From left to right the rotation speed is increased, resulting in an increasing vortex-line density.]] At temperatures below the [[lambda point]], helium shows the unique property of [[superfluidity]]. The fraction of the liquid that forms the superfluid component is a macroscopic [[quantum fluid]]. The helium atom is a [[neutral particle]], so ''q''=0. Furthermore, when considering [[Superfluid helium-4|helium-4]], the relevant particle mass is ''m=m₄'', so Eq.(8) reduces to :{| width=300px | \vec{v}_s=\frac{1}{m_4}\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla}\varphi. | style="text-align:right"|(9) |} For an arbitrary loop in the liquid, this gives :{| width=300px |\oint \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{h}{2\pi m_4} \oint \vec{\nabla}\varphi \cdot \vec{\mathrm{d}s}. | style="text-align:right"|(10) |} Due to the single-valued nature of the wave function :{| width=300px |\oint \vec{\nabla}\varphi \cdot \vec{\mathrm{d}s} = 2\pi n | style="text-align:right"| (11a) |} with ''n'' integer, we have :{| width=300px |\oint \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} =\frac{h}{m_4}n. | style="text-align:right"| (11b) |} The quantity {| width=300px | \kappa =\frac{h}{m_4}=1.0 \times 10^{-7} m^2/s | style="text-align:right"|(12) |} is the quantum of circulation. For a circular motion with radius ''r'' {| width=300px | \oint \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} =2\pi v_sr. | style="text-align:right"|(13) |} In case of a single quantum (''n''=1) {| width=300px | v_s=\frac{1}{2\pi r}\kappa. | style="text-align:right"|(14) |} When superfluid helium is put in rotation, Eq. (13) will not be satisfied for all loops inside the liquid unless the rotation is organized around vortex lines (as depicted in Fig.2). These lines have a vacuum core with a diameter of about 1 Å (which is smaller than the average particle distance). The superfluid helium rotates around the core with very high speeds. Just outside the core (''r'' = 1 Å), the velocity is as large as 160 m/s. The cores of the vortex lines and the container rotate as a solid body around the rotation axes with the same angular velocity. The number of vortex lines increases with the angular velocity (as shown in the upper half of the figure). Note that the two right figures both contain six vortex lines, but the lines are organized in different stable patterns.{{cite journal|author1=E.J. Yarmchuk |author2=R.E. Packard |lastauthoramp=yes |journal=J. Low Temp. Phys.|volume=46|year=1982|page=479|title=Photographic studies of quantized vortex lines|doi=10.1007/BF00683912|bibcode = 1982JLTP...46..479Y|issue=5–6 }} ==Superconductivity== {{main|Superconductivity}} In the original paper{{Cite journal|last=Davidovich|first=Landau, Lev|last2=L|first2=Ginzburg, V|date=1950|title=On the theory of superconductivity|url=http://cds.cern.ch/record/486430|journal=Zh. Eksp. Teor. Fiz.|language=en|volume=20}} Ginzburg and Landau observed the existence of two types of superconductors depending on the energy of the interface between the normal and superconducting states.The [[Meissner state]] breaks down when the applied magnetic field is too large. Superconductors can be divided into two classes according to how this breakdown occurs. In [[Type I superconductor]]s, superconductivity is abruptly destroyed when the strength of the applied field rises above a critical value ''Hc''. Depending on the geometry of the sample, one may obtain an intermediate state {{cite book |author=Lev D. Landau |author2=Evgeny M. Lifschitz |title=Electrodynamics of Continuous Media |series=[[Course of Theoretical Physics]] |volume=8 |publisher=[[Butterworth-Heinemann]] |location=Oxford |date=1984 |isbn=978-0-7506-2634-7 }} consisting of a baroque pattern {{cite journal |author=David J. E. Callaway |date=1990 |title=On the remarkable structure of the superconducting intermediate state |journal = [[Nuclear Physics B]] |volume=344 |pages=627–645 |doi=10.1016/0550-3213(90)90672-Z |issue=3 |bibcode = 1990NuPhB.344..627C }} of regions of normal material carrying a magnetic field mixed with regions of superconducting material containing no field. In [[Type II superconductor]]s, raising the applied field past a critical value ''H''''c''1 leads to a mixed state (also known as the vortex state) in which an increasing amount of [[magnetic flux]] penetrates the material, but there remains no resistance to the flow of electric current as long as the current is not too large. At a second critical field strength ''H''''c''2, superconductivity is destroyed. The mixed state is actually caused by vortices in the electronic superfluid, sometimes called [[fluxon]]s because the flux carried by these vortices is [[quantum|quantized]]. Most pure [[chemical element|elemental]] superconductors, except [[niobium]] and [[carbon nanotube]]s, are Type I, while almost all impure and compound superconductors are Type II. The most important finding from [[Ginzburg–Landau theory]] was made by [[Alexei Alexeyevich Abrikosov|Alexei Abrikosov]] in 1957. He used Ginzburg–Landau theory to explain experiments on superconducting alloys and thin films. He found that in a type-II superconductor in a high magnetic field, the field penetrates in a triangular lattice of quantized tubes of flux [[Abrikosov vortices|vortices]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} ===Fluxoid quantization=== For [[Superconductivity|superconductors]] the bosons involved are the so-called [[Cooper pairs]] which are [[quasiparticle]]s formed by two electrons.{{cite book|author=M. Tinkham|title=Introduction to Superconductivity|publisher= McGraw-Hill |year=1975}} Hence ''m'' = 2''m''e and ''q'' = -2''e'' where ''m''e and ''e'' are the mass of an electron and the elementary charge. It follows from Eq.(8) that :{| width=500px | 2m_e \vec{v}_s=\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla}\varphi+2e\vec{A}. | style="text-align:right"|(15) |} Integrating Eq.(15) over a closed loop gives :{| width=500px | 2m_e\oint \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} = \oint\left(\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla}\varphi+2e\vec{A}\right)\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} | style="text-align:right"|(16) |} As in the case of helium we define the vortex strength :{| width=500px | \oint \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} =\kappa | style="text-align:right"|(17) |} and use the general relation :{| width=500px | \oint \vec{A}\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s} = \Phi | style="text-align:right"|(18) |} where ''Φ'' is the magnetic flux enclosed by the loop. The so-called [[fluxoid]] is defined by :{| width=500px | \Phi_v=\Phi-\frac{2m_e}{2e}\kappa. | style="text-align:right"|(19) |} In general the values of ''κ'' and ''Φ'' depend on the choice of the loop. Due to the single-valued nature of the wave function and Eq.(16) the fluxoid is quantized :{| width=500px | \Phi_v = n\frac{h}{2e}. | style="text-align:right"|(20) |} The unit of quantization is called the [[flux quantum]] :{| width=500px | \Phi_0=\frac{h}{2e} = 2.067833758(46)\times 10^{-15} Wb. | style="text-align:right"|(21) |} The flux quantum plays a very important role in superconductivity. The earth magnetic field is very small (about 50 μT), but it generates one flux quantum in an area of 6 by 6 μm. So, the flux quantum is very small. Yet it was measured to an accuracy of 9 digits as shown in Eq.(21). Nowadays the value given by Eq.(21) is exact by definition. [[File:Superconducting rings01.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig. 3. Two superconducting rings in an applied magnetic field
'''a:''' ''thick superconducting ring. The integration loop is completely in the region with ''v''s=0;''
'''b:''' ''thick superconducting ring with a weak link. The integration loop is completely in the region with ''v''s=0 except for a small region near the weak link.'']] In Fig. 3 two situations are depicted of superconducting rings in an external magnetic field. One case is a thick-walled ring and in the other case the ring is also thick-walled, but is interrupted by a weak link. In the latter case we will meet the famous [[Josephson relations]]. In both cases we consider a loop inside the material. In general a superconducting circulation current will flow in the material. The total magnetic flux in the loop is the sum of the applied flux ''Φ''a and the self-induced flux ''Φ''s induced by the circulation current :{| width=300px | \Phi = \Phi_a + \Phi_s. | style="text-align:right"|(22) |} ===Thick ring=== The first case is a thick ring in an external magnetic field (Fig. 3a). The currents in a superconductor only flow in a thin layer at the surface. The thickness of this layer is determined by the so-called [[London penetration depth]]. It is of μm size or less. We consider a loop far away from the surface so that ''v''s=0 everywhere so ''κ''=0. In that case the fluxoid is equal to the magnetic flux (''Φ''v=''Φ''). If ''v''s=0 Eq.(15) reduces to :{| width=300px | 0=\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla}{\varphi}+2e\vec{A}. | style="text-align:right"|(23) |} Taking the rotation gives :{| width=300px | 0=\frac{h}{2\pi}\vec{\nabla} \times \vec{\nabla}\varphi + 2e \vec{\nabla}\times\vec{A}. | style="text-align:right"|(24) |} Using the well-known relations \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{\nabla}\varphi =0 and \vec{\nabla}\times\vec{A}=\vec{B} shows that the magnetic field in the bulk of the superconductor is zero as well. So, for thick rings, the total magnetic flux in the loop is quantized according to :{| width=300px | \Phi=n\Phi_0. | style="text-align:right"|(25) |} ===Interrupted ring, weak links=== [[File:Point Contact01.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig. 4. Schematic of a weak link carrying a superconducting current ''i''s. The voltage difference over the link is ''V''. The phases of the superconducting wave functions at the left and right side are assumed to be constant (in space, not in time) with values of ''φ''1 and ''φ''2 respectively.]] Weak links play a very important role in modern superconductivity. In most cases weak links are oxide barriers between two superconducting thin films, but it can also be a crystal boundary (in the case of [[High temperature superconductivity|high-Tc superconductor]]s). A schematic representation is given in Fig. 4. Now consider the ring which is thick everywhere except for a small section where the ring is closed via a weak link (Fig. 3b). The velocity is zero except near the weak link. In these regions the velocity contribution to the total phase change in the loop is given by (with Eq.(15)) :{| width=300px | \Delta\varphi^*=-\frac{2\pi}{h}2m_e\int_\delta \vec{v}_s\cdot\vec{\mathrm{d}s}. | style="text-align:right"|(26) |} The line integral is over the contact from one side to the other in such a way that the end points of the line are well inside the bulk of the superconductor where ''v''s=0. So the value of the line integral is well-defined (e.g. independent of the choice of the end points). With Eqs.(19), (22), and (26) :{| width=300px | \Phi_a+\Phi_s+\Phi_0\frac{\Delta\varphi^*}{2\pi}=n\Phi_0. | style="text-align:right"|(27) |} Without proof we state that the supercurrent through the weak link is given by the so-called DC [[Josephson relation]]{{cite journal|author=B.D. Josephson|title=Possible new effects in superconductive tunneling|journal=Phys. Lett.|volume=1 |pages=251–253|year=1962|doi=10.1016/0031-9163(62)91369-0|issue=7|bibcode = 1962PhL.....1..251J }} :{| width=300px | i_s = i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi^*). | style="text-align:right"|(28) |} The voltage over the contact is given by the AC Josephson relation :{| width=300px | V=\frac{1}{2\pi}\frac{h}{2e}\frac{\mathrm{d}\Delta\varphi^*}{\mathrm{d}t}. | style="text-align:right"|(29) |} The names of these relations (DC and AC relations) are misleading since they both hold in DC and AC situations. In the steady state (constant \Delta\varphi^*) Eq.(29) shows that ''V''=0 while a nonzero current flows through the junction. In the case of a constant applied voltage (voltage bias) Eq.(29) can be integrated easily and gives :{| width=300px | \Delta\varphi^*=2\pi\frac{2eV}{h}t. | style="text-align:right"|(30) |} Substitution in Eq.(28) gives :{| width=300px | i_s=i_1\sin(2\pi\frac{2eV}{h}t). | style="text-align:right"|(31) |} This is an AC current. The frequency :{| width=300px | \nu=\frac{2eV}{h}=\frac{V}{\Phi_0} | style="text-align:right"|(32) |} is called the Josephson frequency. One μV gives a frequency of about 500 MHz. By using Eq.(32) the flux quantum is determined with the high precision as given in Eq.(21). The energy difference of a Cooper pair, moving from one side of the contact to the other, is Δ''E'' = 2''eV''. With this expression Eq.(32) can be written as Δ''E'' = ''hν'' which is the relation for the energy of a photon with frequency ''ν''. :The AC Josephson relation (Eq.(29)) can be easily understood in terms of Newton's law, (or from one of the [[London equation]]'s{{Cite journal | last1 = London | first1 = F.| authorlink1 = Fritz London| last2 = London | first2 = H.| authorlink2 = Heinz London| doi = 10.1098/rspa.1935.0048 | title = The Electromagnetic Equations of the Supraconductor | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences | volume = 149 | issue = 866 | pages = 71 | year = 1935 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1935RSPSA.149...71L }}). We start with Newton's law ::\vec F = m \mathrm{d}\vec v_s/\mathrm{d}t. :Substituting the expression for the [[Lorentz force]] ::\vec F = q(\vec E+\vec v_s\times \vec B) :and using the general expression for the co-moving time derivative ::\mathrm{d}\vec v_s/\mathrm{d}t=\partial \vec v_s/\partial t + (1/2)\vec \nabla v_s^2-\vec v_s\times(\vec \nabla\times \vec v_s) :gives ::(q/m)(\vec E+\vec v_s\times \vec B)=\partial \vec v_s/\partial t + (1/2)\vec \nabla v_s^2-\vec v_s\times(\vec \nabla\times \vec v_s). :Eq.(8) gives ::0=\vec\nabla\times\vec v_s + (q/m)\vec\nabla\times\vec A = \vec\nabla\times\vec v_s + (q/m)\vec B :so ::(q/m)\vec E=\partial \vec v_s/\partial t+(1/2) \vec \nabla v_s^2. :Take the line integral of this expression. In the end points the velocities are zero so the ∇v2 term gives no contribution. Using ::\int \vec E\cdot\mathrm{d}\vec l = -V :and Eq.(26), with ''q'' = -2''e'' and ''m'' =2''m''e, gives Eq.(29). ===DC SQUID=== {{main|SQUID}} [[File:DC Squid01.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig. 5. Two superconductors connected by two weak links. A current and a magnetic field are applied.]] [[File:Ic B dependence01.jpg|300px|thumb| Fig. 6. Dependence of the critical current of a DC-SQUID on the applied magnetic field]] Figure 5 shows a so-called DC [[SQUID]]. It consists of two superconductors connected by two weak links. The fluxoid quantization of a loop through the two bulk superconductors and the two weak links demands {| width=300px | \Delta\varphi_a^*=\Delta\varphi^*_b+2\pi\frac{\Phi}{\Phi_0}+2\pi n. | style="text-align:right"|(33) |} If the self-inductance of the loop can be neglected the magnetic flux in the loop ''Φ'' is equal to the applied flux {| width=300px | \Phi=\Phi_a=BA | style="text-align:right"|(34) |} with ''B'' the magnetic field, applied perpendicular to the surface, and ''A'' the surface area of the loop. The total supercurrent is given by {| width=300px | i_s=i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi_a^*)+i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi_b^*). | style="text-align:right"|(35) |} Substitution of Eq(33) in (35) gives {| width=300px | i_s=i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi_b^*+2\pi\frac{\Phi}{\Phi_0})+i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi_b^*). | style="text-align:right"|(36) |} Using a well known geometrical formula we get {| width=300px | i_s=2i_1\sin(\Delta\varphi_b^*+\pi\frac{\Phi}{\Phi_0})\cos(\pi\frac{\Phi_a}{\Phi_0}). | style="text-align:right"|(37) |} Since the sin-function can vary only between −1 and +1 a steady solution is only possible if the applied current is below a critical current given by {| width=300px | i_c=2i_1|\cos(\pi\frac{\Phi_a}{\Phi_0})|. | style="text-align:right"|(38) |} Note that the critical current is periodic in the applied flux with period Φ₀. The dependence of the critical current on the applied flux is depicted in Fig. 6. It has a strong resemblance with the interference pattern generated by a laser beam behind a double slit. In practice the critical current is not zero at half integer values of the flux quantum of the applied flux. This is due to the fact that the self-inductance of the loop cannot be neglected.{{cite journal|author1=A.TH.A.M. de Waele |author2=R. de Bruyn Ouboter |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Quantum-interference phenomena in point contacts between two superconductors|journal=Physica|volume= 41|year=1969|pages=225–254|doi=10.1016/0031-8914(69)90116-5|issue=2|bibcode = 1969Phy....41..225D }} ===Type II superconductivity=== {{main|Type-II superconductor}} [[File:Flux lines in a superconductor01.jpg|350px|thumb| Fig. 7. Magnetic flux lines penetrating a type-II superconductor. The currents in the superconducting material generate a magnetic field which, together with the applied field, result in bundles of quantized flux.]] [[Type-II superconductor|Type-II superconductivity]] is characterized by two critical fields called ''B''c1 and ''B''c2. At a magnetic field ''B''c1 the applied magnetic field starts to penetrate the sample, but the sample is still superconducting. Only at a field of ''B''c2 the sample is completely normal. For fields in between ''B''c1 and ''B''c2 magnetic flux penetrates the superconductor in well-organized patterns, the so-called [[Abrikosov vortex]] lattice similar to the pattern shown in Fig. 2.{{Cite journal | last1 = Essmann | first1 = U. | last2 = Träuble | first2 = H. | doi = 10.1016/0375-9601(67)90819-5 | title = The direct observation of individual flux lines in type II superconductors | journal = Physics Letters A | volume = 24 | issue = 10 | pages = 526 | year = 1967 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1967PhLA...24..526E }} A cross section of the superconducting plate is given in Fig. 7. Far away from the plate the field is homogeneous, but in the material superconducting currents flow which squeeze the field in bundles of exactly one flux quantum. The typical field in the core is as big as 1 tesla. The currents around the vortex core flow in a layer of about 50 nm with current densities on the order of 15{{e|12}} A/m². That corresponds with 15 million ampère in a wire of one mm². ==Dilute quantum gases== The classical types of quantum systems, superconductors and superfluid helium, were discovered in the beginning of the 20th century. Near the end of the 20th century, scientists discovered how to create very dilute atomic or molecular gases, cooled first by [[laser cooling]] and then by [[Evaporative cooling (atomic physics)|evaporative cooling]].{{cite journal|author=Anderson, M.H., Ensher, J.R., Matthews, M.R., Wieman, C.E., and Cornell, E.A.|title=Observation of Bose-Einstein Condensation in a Dilute Atomic Vapor|journal=Science|volume= 269|pages=198–201 |year=1995|doi=10.1126/science.269.5221.198|pmid=17789847|issue=5221|bibcode = 1995Sci...269..198A }} They are trapped using magnetic fields or optical dipole potentials in ultrahigh vacuum chambers. Isotopes which have been used include rubidium (Rb-87 and Rb-85), strontium (Sr-87, Sr-86, and Sr-84) potassium (K-39 and K-40), sodium (Na-23), lithium (Li-7 and Li-6), and hydrogen (H-1). The temperatures to which they can be cooled are as low as a few nanokelvin. The developments have been very fast in the past few years. A team of NIST and the University of Colorado has succeeded in creating and observing vortex quantization in these systems.{{cite journal|author=Schweikhard, V., Coddington, I., Engels, P., Tung, S., and Cornell, E.A.|title=Vortex-Lattice Dynamics in Rotating Spinor Bose-Einstein Condensates|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume=93|page= 210403 |year=2004|bibcode = 2004PhRvL..93c0403N |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.030403|pmid=15323808|issue=3 }} The concentration of vortices increases with the angular velocity of the rotation, similar to the case of superfluid helium and superconductivity. ==See also== *[[Quantum turbulence]] *[[Schrödinger's cat|Schrödinger's cat paradox]] *[[Second sound]] *[[Flux quantization]] *[[Domain wall (magnetism)]] *[[Flux pinning]] *[[Ginzburg–Landau theory]] *[[Husimi Q representation]] *[[Magnetic flux quantum]] *[[N-slit interferometric equation]] *[[Quantum vortex]] *[[Topological defect]] *[[Superconductivity]] *[[Type-I superconductor]] *[[Type-II superconductor]] *[[Meissner effect]] *[[SQUID]] *[[Josephson effect]] *[[Charge density wave]] *[[Chiral magnetic effect]] ==References and footnotes== {{Reflist|35em}} [[Category:Atomic, molecular, and optical physics]] [[Category:Condensed matter physics]] [[Category:Exotic matter]] [[Category:Phases of matter]] [[Category:Quantum mechanics]] [[Category:Quantum phases]]

revision.comment: /* top */ Added conjugate base to infobox
Serious page on a deity should not be discussing Touhou project. Poorly sourced, not notable, trivia, and recentism.
revision.text:
{{Shinto}} '''Moreya''' or '''Moriya''' (洩矢神 ''Moreya (Moriya)-no-Kami'' or ''Moreya (Moriya)-shin'') is a Japanese [[Kami|deity]] who appears in various myths and legends of the [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa]] region in [[Nagano Prefecture]] (historical [[Shinano Province]]). The most famous of such stories is his battle and subsequent defeat under the hands of Suwa [[Myōjin|(Dai)myōjin]] (諏訪大明神) a.k.a. [[Takeminakata]], the god of the [[Suwa taisha|Grand Shrine of Suwa]], who in one version of the myths about him was supposed to have established his rule in the region by subjugating local deities who resisted him. Moreya is also held to be the ancestor of the Moriya clan (守矢氏), who originally served in one of Suwa Shrine's two sub-shrines, the Upper Shrine (上社 ''Kamisha'') as the ''Jinchōkan'' (神長官), a priest subservient to the Upper Shrine's head priest, the ''Ōhōri'' (大祝), a young boy of the [[Suwa clan]] believed to be Suwa Myōjin's living incarnation. The ''Jinchōkan'', a hereditary position passed down from father to son, occupied an important position in the Upper Shrine due to his prerogative to call upon the [[Mishaguji]], local [[List of agricultural gods|agricultural]] and [[List of fertility gods|fertility deities]] worshiped in Suwa since time immemorial and who occupied a central place in many of the Upper Shrine's religious ceremonies. Due to the similarity of their names, Moreya has been for a long time conflated with the anti-Buddhist ''[[Muraji|Ōmuraji]]'' [[Mononobe no Moriya]], who was defeated by the pro-Buddhist [[Soga clan]] in 587. ==Name== Two documents dated to the mid-1230s ([[Katei|Katei era]]) name a ''Moriya-no-Ōkami''/''Daijin'' (守矢之大神 or 守矢太神), which are probable early references to the god and/or a shrine to him.''Norito-dan'' (祝詞段), in {{cite book|editor=Shinano-shiryō kankōkai|title=信濃史料 巻十六 (Shinano-shiryō, vol. 16)|date=1961|publisher=Shinano-shiryō kankōkai|page=271|url=https://trc-adeac.trc.co.jp/Html/BookletView/2000710100/2000710100100010/1603/?pagecode=72}}''Kongenki'' (根元記), in {{cite book|editor=Shinano-shiryō kankōkai|title=信濃史料 巻十六 (Shinano-shiryō, vol. 16)|date=1961|page=312|url=https://trc-adeac.trc.co.jp/Html/BookletView/2000710100/2000710100100010/1603/?pagecode=113}}{{cite web|title=嘉禎の旧記|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/katei.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}{{cite web|title=洩矢神社 岡谷市川岸橋原|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/moreya.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} What is currently the most common rendering of Moreya's name in [[kanji]] (洩矢) appear in sources such as the ''[[Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba]]'' (1356), where the god is pejoratively referred to as an 'evil outlaw' (洩矢の悪賊 ''Moreya no akuzoku''), and the written genealogy of the Moriya clan, the ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu'' (early [[Meiji period]]). It is also the rendering adopted by Moriya Shrine (洩矢神社) in [[Okaya, Nagano|Okaya City]] in Nagano.{{cite web|url=https://moriyajinja.amebaownd.com/|title=Moriya Shrine Official Website (洩矢神社公式HP)}} In addition, a number of texts (see below) refer to the god as ''Moriya Daijin'' (守屋大臣 'Chancellor Moriya'), an epithet also used for the historical [[Mononobe no Moriya]].''Nihon Kōtei Keizu'' (日本皇帝系図), in {{cite book|editor1=Hanawa Hokiichi|title=群書系図部集 第二 (Gunsho keizubushū, vol. 2)|date=1973|publisher=Zoku Gunsho-ruijū Kanseikai|page=51|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dxv_wsnc14YC&pg=RA1-PA19}}{{cite book|last1=Dickson|first1=Walter G.|title=Gleanings from Japan|date=1889|publisher=W. Blackwood and Sons|page=360|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gR8QAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA360}}{{cite book|last1=Arai|first1=Hakuseki|translator=Joly, Henri L. |translator2=Inada, Hogitarō|title=The Sword Book in Honchō Gunkikō and the Book of Samé Ko Hi Sei Gi of Inaba Tsurio|date=1963|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=JWceAAAAIAAJ&q=moriya+daijin|page=14}} Finally, the rendering 守宅{{cite book|editor1-last=Fukuyama|editor1-first=Toshihisa|title=信濃史蹟 (Suwa shiseki)|date=1912|publisher=Shinano shinbunsha|page=18－19|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/765072/29}} {{ja icon}} is also attested, although this is more commonly applied to Moreya's son, Moriya/Morita (see below). ==Mythology== ===Battle with Suwa Myōjin=== [[File:Wisteria_floribunda5.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Wisteria floribunda|Japanese wisteria]] (''Wisteria floribunda'').]] The most famous story involving Moreya is that of his conflict against the god of [[Suwa taisha|Suwa Grand Shrine]], known either as [[Takeminakata]] (the name given to him in the ''[[Kojiki]]'' and [[Rikkokushi|the official histories]]) or as Suwa (Dai)myōjin. The basic gist of this myth in most sources involves a certain god (in most sources identified with Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata) defeating Moreya, who is often described as armed with a certain kind of iron weapon or implement, using only a branch or vine of [[wisteria]].Moriya, Sanae (1991). ''Moriya-jinchō-ke no ohanashi'' (守矢神長家のお話し). In Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum (Ed.). ''Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan no shiori'' (神長官守矢資料館のしおり) (Rev. ed.). pp. 2–3. {{ja icon}}Miyasaka, Mitsuaki (1987). "Kyodai naru kami no kuni. Suwa-shinkō no tokushitsu (強大なる神の国―諏訪信仰の特質)." In Miyasaka, Mitsuaki (1987). "Kyodai naru kami no kuni. Suwa-shinkō no tokushitsu (強大なる神の国―諏訪信仰の特質)." In {{cite book|author1=Ueda|author2=Gorai|author3=Ōbayashi|author4=Miyasaka, M.|author5=Miyasaka, Y.|script-title=ja:御柱祭と諏訪大社 |title=Onbashira-sai to Suwa-taisha |location=Nagano|publisher=Chikuma Shobō|isbn=978-4480841810|page=21 |language=ja}}{{cite book|author=Oh, Amana ChungHae|title=Cosmogonical Worldview of Jomon Pottery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hxulspIN_2UC&pg=PA157-158|date=2011|publisher=Sankeisha|isbn=978-4-88361-924-5|pages=157-159}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Yazaki|editor1-first=Takenori|title=Suwa-taisha |script-title=ja:諏訪大社 |date=1986|publisher=Ginga shobō|series=Ginga gurafikku sensho|volume=4|pages=24-25 |language=ja}}{{cite book|editor=Rekishi REAL Henshūbu (歴史REAL編集部) |title=Jinja to kodai gōzoku no nazo |script-title=ja:神社と古代豪族の謎 |date=2016|publisher=Yosensha|isbn=978-4800308924|page=39 |language=ja}} Some versions of the story end with the triumphant god planting or discarding the branch, which then turns into a tree or a whole forest of wisterias. ====In the ''Kamisha Monoimi-rei''==== ====In Suwa Nobushige's petition==== The earliest written version of this myth is found in a petition (解状 ''gejō'') submitted by Suwa Nobushige (諏訪信重), then high priest (''[[Suwa clan|Ōhōri]]'') of the Upper Shrine of Suwa, to the [[Kamakura shogunate]] in 1249.Miyasaka (1987), p. 21.Miyasaka (1992), pp. 92-93. The Upper Shrine was at the time involved in a dispute with the high priest of the Lower Shrine as to which of them was the main shrine of the area, and thus, is to set a precedent in religious rites. Against the Lower Shrine's charges, Nobushige argued for his own shrine's superiority by describing its origin myths and its ceremonies.{{cite book|editor=Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai (諏訪市史編纂委員会)|title=Suwa Shishi, vol. 1 |script-title=諏訪市史 上巻 原始・古代・中世 |date=1995|location=Suwa|pages=811-814|chapter='Ōhōri Nobushige gejō' to 'Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba' |script-chapter=ja:「大祝信重解状」と『諏方大明神画詞』}} In the petition, Nobushige relates a story from "the ancient customs" (舊貫) that the Upper Shrine's precincts was once the land of 'Moriya Daijin' (守屋大臣, lit. 'Chancellor Moriya'), who got into a dispute with a god (明神 ''[[Myōjin]]'') who came down from heaven and was seeking to gain possession of his land. After arguments and armed conflicts fail to settle the matter, the two finally compete in a [[tug of war]] using hooks (''kagi'') made out of [[wisteria]] (藤鎰) and iron (鐵鎰). After his victory, the god imposed punishment on Moriya and built his dwelling (what would become the Upper Shrine) in Moriya's land. The wisteria, which was planted before the god's dwelling, turned into a grove known as the 'Forest of Fujisuwa' (藤諏訪之森 ''Fujisuwa no mori''), which in turn gave its name to the region.{{efn|「一 守屋山麓御垂跡事
右謹檢舊貫、當砌昔者守屋大臣之所領也、大神天降御之刻、大臣者奉禦明神之居住、勵制止之方法、明神者廻可爲御敷地之祕計、或致諍論、或及合戰之處、兩方難決雌雄、爰明神者持藤鎰、大臣者以鐵鎰、懸此所引之、明神即以藤鎰令勝得軍陣之諍論給、而間令追罰守屋大臣、卜居所當社以來、遙送數百歲星霜、久施我神之稱譽天下給、應跡之方々是新哉、明神以彼藤鎰自令植當社之前給、藤榮枝葉號藤諏訪之森、毎年二ヶ度御神事勤之、自尓以來以當郡名諏方、爰下宮者當社依夫婦之契約示姫大明神之名、然而當大明神、若不令追出守屋給者、爭兩者卜居御哉、自天降之元初爲本宮之條炳焉者哉、」}}{{cite book|last1=Miyachi|first1=Naokazu|script-title=ja:諏訪史 第二卷 前編 |title=Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 1 |date=1931a|publisher=信濃教育会諏訪部会 (Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hBVjsO2GOgC&pg=PA15|page=76 |language=ja}}{{cite book|last1=Miyachi|first1=Naokazu |script-title=ja:諏訪史 第二卷 後編 |title=Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 2 |date=1931b|publisher=信濃教育会諏訪部会 (Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UHYSgY4lTZcC|pages=47-48 |language=ja}}''Suwa Nobushige Gejō'' (諏訪信重解状), in {{cite book|editor=Suwa Kyōikukai (諏訪教育会)|title=諏訪史料叢書 巻15 (Suwa shiryō-sōsho, vol. 15)|date=1931|location=Suwa|publisher=Suwa Kyōikukai |language=ja}} In a later passage, Nobushige states that the god brought a [[Bronze mirror|mirror]] (真澄の鏡 ''Masumi no kagami''), a [[Suzu|bell]] (八栄の鈴 ''Yasaka no suzu''), a [[bridle]] (轡) and a [[saddle]] (唐鞍) with him during his descent from heaven, which were preserved in his day as the Upper Shrine's sacred treasures.{{efn|「一 御神寶物事
右大明神天降給之刻、所令御隨身之眞澄鏡、八榮鈴並唐鞍、轡等在之、御鏡者數百歳之間無陰曇、鈴者其音無替、毎年二ヶ度大祝向彼鏡振件鈴致天下泰平之祈請、鞍轡等其色不損 (...)」}}Miyachi (1931b). p. 126.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). "Suwa-jinja Kamisha Shimosha (諏訪神社上社・下社)". pp. 681-683. ====In the ''Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba'' and the ''Suwa Daimyojin Kōshiki''==== [[File:Fujishima Shrine (藤島社).png|thumb|Fujishima Shrine during the early 20th century.]] What is perhaps the most well-known version of the story occurs in Suwa (Kosaka) Enchū's ''[[Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba]]'' (1356) as an [[origin myth]] of Fujishima Shrine (藤島社 ''Fujishima-sha'' or 藤島大明神 ''Fujishima Daimyōjin'') in [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]], one of the Upper Shrine's [[Setsumatsusha|auxiliary shrines]] where its yearly rice-planting ceremony is traditionally held.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 88-91.{{cite web|title=藤島社・藤島大明神|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/hujisimasya.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}{{cite web|title=諏訪大社上社「御田植祭」|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sinji/otaue.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} In this version, Moreya is described as an "evil outlaw" (洩矢の悪賊 ''Moreya no akuzoku'') using a ring of iron (鐵輪) as his weapon. {{Quote|End [of June] - The rice-planting ritual.
The following ceremony is held before Fujishima Shrine (藤島社): the ''Ōhōri'', the priests and other men and women don fresh clothes and come to this place. [[Gagaku]] [musicians], bearing farming tools, till the rice fields. With [[Suwa_taisha#Kamisha|the five chief priests]] (五官) presiding over the proceedings, [[Miko|the shrine maidens]] act as rice planters (''saotome''); appointed performers (職掌 ''shikishō''), meanwhile, beat [[Tsuzumi|drums]], clap, sing and dance with ''[[Binzasara|sasara]]'' in their hands. (...) After thirty days the rice ripens and is presented as an offering to the god [of [[Suwa taisha|Suwa Shrine]]] in the first of August. This is one of the [Upper] Shrine's wonders.
As for this so-called Fujishima no Myōjin (藤島明神): long ago, when the revered deity (尊神 ''sonshin'') [[Honji suijaku|manifested himself]], Moreya the evil outlaw (洩矢の惡賊) sought to hinder the god's stay and fought him with an iron ring (鐵輪), but the ''Myōjin'', taking up a wisteria branch (藤の枝), defeated him, thus finally subduing heresy (邪輪 ''jarin'', lit. "wheel/circle/ring of evil") and establishing [[Dharma (Buddhism)|the true Dharma]]. When the Myōjin swore an oath and threw the wisteria branch away, immediately it took root [in the ground], its branches and leaves flourishing in abundance, and [sprouted] beautiful blossoms, leaving behind a marker of the battleground for posterity. 'Fujishima no Myōjin' is named thus for this reason.{{efn|「晦日。田植。藤島社の前にして此儀あり。大祝の外。神官男女衣服を刷て此所に望む。雅樂農具を帶して田がへす。五官を行事とし。巫女をさうとめとす。職掌大鞁を取。拍子をうち。笛を吹。さゝらを取て歌舞す。(...) 卅日をへて熟稻と成て。八月一日神供に備。當社奇特の其一なり。
抑此藤島の明神と申は。尊神垂迹の昔。洩矢の惡賊神居をさまたげんとせし時。洩矢は鐵輪を持してあらそひ。明神は藤枝を取りて是を伏し給ふ。終に邪輪を降して正法を興す。明神誓を發て。藤枝をなげ給しかば。則根をさして枝葉をさかへ花蘂あざやかにして。戰場のしるしを萬代に殘す。藤島の明神と號此故也。」}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Hanawa|editor1-first=Hokiichi|title=Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba |script-title=ja:諏訪大明神繪詞 |date=1914|publisher=Zoku Gunsho-ruijū Kanseikai|series=[[Gunsho Ruijū|Zoku Gunsho-ruijū]] (続群書類従)|volume=3|page=530|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/63 |language=ja}}{{cite book|last1=Kanai|first1=Tenbi|title=Suwa-shinkō-shi |script-title=ja:諏訪信仰史 |date=1982|publisher=Meicho Shuppan|page=262 |language=ja}}}} A record of the Upper Shrine's regulations or [[taboos]] (物忌み ''monoimi''){{cite web|last1=Iwai|first1=Hiroshi|title=Monoimi|url=http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1458|website=Encyclopedia of Shinto|publisher=Kokugakuin University}} originally enforced in 1238, the ''Suwa Kamisha butsuki'' (or: ''monoimi no'') ''rei no koto'' (諏訪上社物忌令之事),{{cite journal|last1=Takei|first1=Masahiro|script-title=ja:祭事を読む-諏訪上社物忌令之事- |title=Saiji wo yomu: Suwa Kamisha butsukirei no koto |journal=飯田市美術博物館 研究紀要 (Bulletin of the Iida City Museum)|date=1999|volume=9|pages=121–144|url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110008434555}} lists 'Fujishima Daimyōjin' as the first of thirteen middle-rank auxiliary shrines of the ''Kamisha'' (中十三所 ''Chū-jūsansho'') and identifies its god as a [[Honji suijaku|manifestation]] of the wrathful [[Wisdom King]] [[Acala]] (aka Fudō-Myōō).Takei (1999). p. 135. Nowadays, the shrine is instead considered to be dedicated to the goddess [[Konohanasakuya-hime|Konohana-Sakuya-Hime]].Miyasaka (1992). p. 91. The myth is retold in a substantially similar fashion in a [[Shinbutsu-shūgō|Shinto-Buddhist]] liturgical eulogy (講式 ''kōshiki'') to the Suwa deity believed to have been composed by Enchū around the same time as the ''Ekotoba'' known as the ''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki'' (諏方大明神講式).{{cite web|title=諏方大明神講式|url=http://base1.nijl.ac.jp/iview/Frame.jsp?DB_ID=G0003917KTM&C_CODE=KSRM-287105|website=National Institute of Japanese Literature (国文学研究資料館)}}諏方大明神講式 (''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki''), in {{cite book|title=神道大系 神社編３０ 諏訪 (Shintō Taikei Jinja-hen, 30: Suwa)|date=1982|publisher=Shintō Taikei Hensankai|editor=Shintō Taikei Hensankai|location=Tokyo|pages=9, 237ff.}}{{cite book|last1=Fukuda|first1=Akira|last2=Nihonmatsu|first2=Yasuhiro|last3=Tokuda|first3=Kazuo|title=諏訪信仰の中世―神話・伝承・歴史 (Suwa Shinko no Chusei: Shinwa, Densho, Rekishi)|date=2015|publisher=Miyai Shoten|isbn=978-4838232888|page=119-123}} ====In Suwa clan genealogies==== Two genealogies of the [[Suwa clan]], the ''Maeda-bon Jinshi Keizu'' ([[:ja:前田本|前田本]] 神氏系図)神氏系図 (''Jinshi Keizu''), in {{cite book|author1=Miyachi, Naokazu (宮地直一)|script-title=ja:諏訪史 第二卷 前編 |title=Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 1 |date=1931|publisher=Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai (信濃教育会諏訪部会)|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1076393/166}}{{cite book|editor=Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai|title=古代諏訪の祭祀と氏族 (Kodai Suwa no Saishi to Shizoku)|date=2017|publisher=Ningen-sha (人間社)|isbn=978-4908627163|page=88 |language=ja}} and the ''Jinke Keizu'' (神家系図),神家系図 (''Jinke Keizu''), in {{cite book|editor=Suwa Kyōikukai (諏訪教育会)|script-title=諏訪史料叢書 巻28 |title=Suwa shiryō-sōsho, vol. 28 |date=1931|location=Suwa|publisher=Suwa Kyōikukai|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1185913/9 |language=ja}} contain a somewhat [[Euhemerism|euhemerized]] variant of the myth: the battle is placed during the reign of the [[Emperor Yōmei]] (reigned 585-587), Moreya - again referred to as 'Moriya (Daijin)' (守屋(大臣)) - is apparently conflated with the anti-Buddhist ''[[Muraji|ōmuraji]]'' [[Mononobe no Moriya]] (died 587), and Suwa Myōjin fights the battle through his avatar, the boy priest [[Takeminakata#The_Misogi-hōri|Arikazu]] (有員).{{efn|「神幸信州諏方郡者、人皇卅二代用明天皇御宇也。于時、有八歳童子後字有員而令隨遂明神守屋奉諍。大神至守屋山、有御合戰。童子率神兵、追落守屋。則于彼山麓構社壇。吾神脱着御衣於童子。『吾無躰、以祝爲躰。』有神勅、隱給御身。即彼童子爲神躰、名御衣木祝、神氏始祖也。明神者普賢、童子者文殊也。」}}{{efn|「用明天皇御宇、大明神影向信濃國諏方郡之時、爲有員童子形体、令御共也。爰同郡守屋大臣奉諍。大明神御來臨之間、至守屋山、彼大臣與大明神在御合戰。于時、有員令御共致合戰、忠追落大臣。則於守屋山麓構社壇、令化現諏訪大明神。即有員始而爲祝奉成祭禮者也。豈大明神者普賢、有員者文殊師利菩薩化身云々。]}} A [[Muromachi period]] work authored by [[Rinzai]] monk Ten'in Ryūtaku (天隠龍沢, 1422-1500){{cite web|title=天隠竜沢|url=https://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%A4%A9%E9%9A%A0%E7%AB%9C%E6%B2%A2-1093213|website=kotobank - デジタル版 日本人名大辞典+Plus|publisher=Kōdansha, The Asahi Shimbun Company, VOYAGE GROUP, Inc.}} known as the ''Ten'in-goroku'' (天陰語録) recounts this variant of the myth: here, Arikazu was said to have defeated Moreya/Moriya "at the time of the 32nd human sovereign Emperor Yōmei, (when) [[Buddhism in Japan#Asuka Period (538 to 710) and Nara Period (710–794)|Buddhism spread to the east]]." (人皇卅二代用明天皇、佛法東流之時){{efn|「神之顯於科野國者。人皇卅二代用明天皇佛法東流之時也。有八歲童子。其名爲有員。隨神以信州也。大臣守屋拒之。童子率兵神以力戰。守屋敗績。弃甲以走。童子追之。就守屋城下。」}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Hanawa|editor1-first=Hokiichi|title=''Ten'in-goroku'' (天陰語録)|date=1914|publisher=Zoku Gunsho-ruijū Kanseikai|series=''[[Gunsho Ruijū|Zoku Gunsho-ruijū]]'' (続群書類従)|volume=13|page=413|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c0Fjxu9FS4EC&pg=PA65&lpg=PA65 |language=ja}} ====In the ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu''==== The ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu'' (神長守矢氏系譜), a genealogy of the Moriya clan compiled at the beginning of the [[Meiji period]] by Moriya Saneyoshi (守矢実久),''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu'' (神長守矢氏系図), in {{cite book|editor=Suwa Kyōikukai (諏訪教育会)|script-title=ja:諏訪史料叢書 巻28 |title=Suwa shiryō-sōsho, vol. 28 |date=1931|location=Suwa|publisher=Suwa Kyōikukai|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1185913/24 |language=ja}}{{cite book|last1=Ōta|first1=Akira|script-title=ja:諏訪神社誌 第1巻 |title=Suwa-jinja-shi: Volume 01 |date=1926|pages=15–16|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/983470/17 |language=ja}}''Suwa-jinja-kyūki'' (諏訪神社旧記), as cited in {{cite book|last1=Miyachi|first1=Naokazu|script-title=ja:諏訪史 第二卷 前編 |title=Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 1 |date=1931|publisher=信濃教育会諏訪部会 (Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hBVjsO2GOgC&pg=PA15|page=76}} meanwhile identifies Moreya's opponent with Takeminakata as he appears in both the ''[[Kojiki]]'' and the ''[[Sendai Kuji Hongi]]'': a god driven away from [[Izumo Province|the land of Izumo]]. {{Quote|When Minakatatomi-no-Mikoto (御名方刀美命) fled from Izumo to the [[Lake Suwa|sea of Suwa]], the god Moreya (洩矢神) who was dwelling by its shores - a shrine [to whom] is found in [[Okaya, Nagano|the village of Hashihara]] - resisted him. Though they fought each other using wisteria and iron ''kagi'' (藤鑰鐵鑰), [Moreya] finally submitted to the august power of Minakatatomi-no-Mikoto, vowing to give up the land for the god to govern politically and religiously (祭政). Minakatatomi-no-Mikoto recited the following [[Waka (poetry)|song]]: :([[Man'yōgana]]) 鹿兒弓乃 眞弓乎持弖 宮滿茂里 矢竹心爾 仕布麻都連與 :''Kagoyumi no'' / ''mayumi o mochite'' / ''miya mamori'' / ''yatake-gokoro ni'' / ''tsukaumatsureyo'' :("Wielding your bow / made of [[Euonymus hamiltonianus|spindle wood]], / protect my dwelling (or 'shrine') / and attend to me / stout-heartedly!") He then planted the wisteria [on the ground], which later grew and became known as the Forest of Fujisuwa (藤洲羽森).{{efn|「洩矢神：御名方刀美命、逃出雲到于洲羽海之時、有洩矢神者居海畔(橋原村社有)拒之、藤鑰鐵鑰以雖有互相爭事、遂服御名方富命御稜威、誓曰奉乎地永主命之祭政。御名方刀美命歌曰、鹿兒弓乃眞弓乎持弖宮滿茂里矢竹心爾仕布麻都連與。揷彼藤、後繫茂弖曰藤洲羽森。」}}}} ===Moreya and Yatsukao/Ganigawara=== Another myth involving Moreya concerns the defeat of the god '''Yatsukao-no-Mikoto''' (矢塚男命) also known as '''Ganigawara''' (蟹河原長者 ''Ganigawara-chōja'') of Tenpaku-shime Shrine (天白七五三社) in [[Chino, Nagano|Chino City]].Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai, ed. (2017). p 79.{{cite web|title=蟹河原（がにがわら）|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/kani.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}{{cite web|title=蟹河原 （茅野市ちの横内）|url=http://tateshina-times.jp/?p=7866|website=たてしなの時間|publisher=蓼科企画}} {{Quote|There is an oral tradition that the shrine's god, Yatsukao-no-Mikoto, dwelt inside a cave in this area ... When Takeminakata-no-Mikoto came to this land, he (Yatsukao?) fought Moreya-no-Kami with bow and arrow. When Yatsukao was struck by the arrow and was about to die, he said to Takeminakata-no-Mikoto, "I should have submitted to you, O great god! I have a daughter - I give her to you." After saying this, he died.''Shinano-no-kuni Kansha Suwa-jinja Jinchōkan Moriya-ke Ryaku-keizu'' (信濃國官社諏訪神社神長官守矢家略系圖), in {{cite book|author1=Nobukawa, Kazuhiko (延川和彦)|author2=Iida, Kotaro (飯田好太郎)|title=諏訪氏系図 続編 (Suwa-shi Keizu, Zokuhen)|date=1921|page=19|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/927368/21}}{{efn|「永明村天白七五三社由緒ニ、字宮渡祭神矢塚男命此地ニ穴居ス、健御名方命此國ニ到リシ時洩矢神ト弓矢を以テ戦フ、矢塚男其矢ニ中リテ死セントシ、建御名方命ニ云フ、我ハ大神ニ随フベシ、一女アリ献ラムト言ヒ終テ死ストノ口傳アリ (下畧)」}}}} A folk version of the story states that after Moreya's defeat in the hands of the Suwa deity (identified here with Takeminakata of Izumo), Ganigawara, a powerful and wealthy god/chieftain in the region, held Moreya in contempt for surrendering to the foreign god and even had messengers publicly revile him as a coward. When Moreya paid no heed to their insults, Ganigawara's servants began to resort to violence, shooting arrows at the palace Moreya and other deities were erecting for Takeminakata. Takeminakata, considering it an affront, then launched an all-out attack against Ganigawara, who was caught unprepared and thus, was quickly defeated. Ganigawara, mortally wounded by an arrow in the assault, repents in his deathbed and, via Moreya, entrusts his youngest daughter to Takeminakata. Takeminakata gives her hand in marriage to Taokihooi-no-Mikoto (手置帆負命) a.k.a. Hikosashiri/Hikosachi-no-Kami (彦狭知神){{efn|Both Taokihooi and Hikosachi - identified as two distinct individuals - appear in the ''[[Nihon Shoki]]''{{cite wikisource |title=Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|wslink=Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|chapter=Book II |last=Aston |first=William George |authorlink=William George Aston |year=1896 |publisher=Kegan Paul, Trench, Trübner & Co. |location=London |page=81 |pages= |scan=Page:Nihongi_by_Aston.djvu/112|quote=Thereupon Ta-oki-ho-ohi no Kami, ancestor of the Imbe of the Land of Kii, was appointed hatter, Hiko-sachi no Kami was made shield-maker ...}}{{cite wikisource |wslink=zh:日本書紀|chapter=卷第二|title=日本書紀|quote=既以紀伊國忌部遠祖手置帆負神、定爲作笠者。狹知神、爲作盾者。}} and the ''[[Kogo Shūi]]''{{cite wikisource |wslink=zh:古語拾遺|title=古語拾遺|quote=手置帆負命。讚岐國忌部祖也。產狹知命。紀伊國忌部祖也。}} as ancestors of the Inbe clan (忌部氏).}}, who was injured by Ganigawara's messengers as he was keeping watch over Takeminakata's abode. Taokihooi then settled down with his new wife in Ganigawara's land, which he also inherited.{{cite book|author1=Imai, Nogiku (今井野菊)|title=諏訪ものがたり (Suwa Monogatari)|date=1960|publisher=Kōyō Shobō (甲陽書房)|pages=42-49|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/9543689}} [[File:Mt.Moriya from Mt.Akadake.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Mount Moriya as seen from [[Mount Aka (Yatsugatake)|Mount Aka]] (part of the [[Yatsugatake Mountains]]).]] ===The rain god of Mount Moriya=== Behind the Upper Shrine of Suwa, straddling the border between the cities of [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa]] and [[Ina, Nagano|Ina]], stands the 1,650 metre-highYazaki (1986). p. 96.{{cite web|title=守屋山|url=http://www8.shinmai.co.jp/yama/guide/00063.html|website=信州山岳ガイド|publisher=The Shinano Mainichi Shimbun}} Mount Moriya ([[:ja:守屋山|守屋山]] ''Moriya-san''), which is often claimed to be the shrine's ''[[Shintai|go-shintai]]''.{{cite web|title=Suwa Taisha Shrine|url=http://www.japanvisitor.com/japan-temples-shrines/suwa-shrine-nagano|website=Japan Visitor}} The god of this mountain, usually called Moriya Daijin (守屋大臣), identified with either MoreyaMiyasaka (1992). p. 93. (in Suwa Nobushige's petition, the ''Maeda-bon Jinshi Keizu'', and the ''Jinke Keizu'', the mountain is portrayed as the battleground between Suwa Myōjin/the priest Arikazu and 'Moriya Daijin') or Mononobe no Moriya (a miniature shrine or ''[[hokora]]'' located on the mountain's peak is currently considered as the rear [[Setsumatsusha|shrine]] or ''oku no miya'' (奥宮) of a shrine to the Mononobe chancellor on the slopes of the mountain{{cite web|title=物部守屋を祀る物部守屋神社|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/moriya.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}), is traditionally held as a [[Weather god|weather deity]] who causes rain to fall when angered.Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai, ed. (2017). pp. 80-81. Local [[Rainmaking (ritual)|rainmaking rituals]] once involved provoking the god into sending rain by vandalizing the ''hokora'' or throwing it down the mountain side. [[File:Hokora in Mount Moriya (守屋山上の祠).png|thumb|The ''hokora'' (fenced by a wooden barricade) at the peak of Mount Moriya during the early 20th century. The ''hokora'' was once the target of ritual desecration by locals whenever rain was needed.]]Popular belief holds that rain falls whenever clouds gather around the mountain top.Yazaki (1986). p. 96. A local folk song advises people to prepare to mow the fields whenever the following signs of incoming rain are observed: {{Quote|:([[Man'yōgana]]) 於自理皮礼 守矢敞雲乎 巻上而 百舌鳥義智奈哿婆 鎌遠登具倍斯 :(おじり晴れ 守矢へ雲を 巻き上げて もずぎち鳴かば 鎌をとぐべし) :''Ojiri hare'' / ''Moriya e kumo o'' / ''maki agete'' / ''mozu gichi nakaba'' / ''kama o togu beshi'' :"When the sun at [[Tenryū River|Ojiri]] / pushes clouds / towards (Mount) Moriya / and the [[Bull-headed shrike|shrike]] (''mozu'') chatters / sharpen your sickles."{{cite web|title=物部守屋神社奥宮(守屋山の主は…)|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/moriyasan.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}}} ===Offspring=== The ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu'' claims Moreya to have had two children, a daughter named Tamaru-hime (多満留姫) and a son named Moriya{{cite book|last1=Ōwa|first1=Iwao|title=Jinja to kodai minkan saishi (神社と古代民間祭祀)|date=1989|publisher=Hakusuisha|isbn=978-4560022269|page=40}} {{ja icon}} (守宅神 or 守矢神) or Morita-no-Kami (守田神).{{efn|「守宅神：生弖有靈異幹力、代父弖負弓矢、從大神遊獵得千鹿。有一男、名之曰千鹿頭神。」}}Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum (Ed.) (1991). ''Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan no shiori'' (神長官守矢資料館のしおり) (Rev. ed.). p. 10. Tamaru-hime married Izuhayao (出速雄神), a son of Takeminakata,{{efn|「洩矢神 (...) 有一男一女、女曰多滿留姫、嫁大神御子出速雄神。」}} while Morita became the father of the god Chikatō (千鹿頭神), who married Urako-hime (宇良古比売命), the goddess of Mount Urako (宇良古山) in modern-day [[Matsumoto, Nagano|Matsumoto City]].{{efn|「千鹿頭社　諏訪郡ノ内鎭座　　有賀　上原
原田　横吹　休戸　　東筑摩郡　神田　林
同地宇良古山ニ鎭座ス往古ハ郡内三十餘村ノ祭神ナリ 后神ヲ宇良古比賣命ト云口碑ニ傳フ由同地ニ命ノ社アリ」}}{{cite web|title=千鹿頭神・宇良古山・宿世結神・逢初川　(松本市神田・林)|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/jinja/urako.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} Curiously, according to the genealogy Chikatō was succeeded by Kodamahiko (児玉彦命), the son of Katakurabe (片倉辺命), another one of Takeminakata's children, under the orders of the god himself. Kodamahiko was said to have married Mitsutama-hime (美都多麻比売神), the daughter of Moritatsu (守達神) - identified in the genealogy as yet another son of Takeminakata{{efn|「守達神：健御名方命之御子也。」}} - and begat the god Yakushi (八櫛神).{{efn|「兒玉彦命：大神御子片倉邊命之御子也。大神之御言之隨、千鹿頭神之跡乎繼弖主祭政。守達神御子、美都多麻比賣神乎娶弖、八櫛神乎生。」}} ==Analysis== The story of Moreya's battle against Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata/Arikazu has been interpreted either as a mythicization of a conflict between indigenous [[Jōmon period|Jōmon]] [[hunter-gatherers]] of the Suwa region and [[Agrarian society|agrarian]] [[Yayoi period|Yayoi peoples]] who began to settle in the area,{{cite journal|last1=Tanaka|first1=Atsuko|title=古社叢の「聖地」の構造（3）─諏訪大社の場合|journal=Journal of Kyoto Seika University|pages=122–123|url=http://www.kyoto-seika.ac.jp/researchlab/wp/wp-content/uploads/kiyo/pdf-data/no39/tanaka_atsuko.pdf}} {{ja icon}}{{cite AV media|title = 古代史ミステリー 「御柱」～最後の"縄文王国"の謎～ (Kodaishi Mystery. Onbashira: Saigo no Jōmon-ōkoku no nazo)|medium=Documentary|publisher=NHK|location=Japan|date = 2016|url=http://www.nhk.or.jp/docudocu/program/46/2586790/}} {{ja icon}} or between the local clans of Suwa and the expanding [[Yamato period|Yamato state]] somewhere during the 6th to 7th centuries CE ([[Asuka period]]).Miyasaka (1987), pp. 18-22.Oh (2011), pp. 156-157. Accordingly, Moreya is believed by some to be a deified indigenous priest-chieftain or clan leader who once held political and religious authority over the Suwa region.Oh (2011). pp. 158-159. The author [[:ja:大和岩雄|Iwao Ōwa]] (1990) meanwhile theorizes Moreya to be a personification of the guardian nature spirit or [[Mishaguji]] worshipped by the Moriya clan. He further proposes that Moreya/Moriya and Moriya/Morita - Moreya's son in the ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu'' - were originally a single figure later split into two, with the elder Moriya (Moreya) being connected with hunting and the younger Moriya (Morita) being mostly associated with sedentary agriculture.{{cite book|last1=Ōwa|first1=Iwao|title=Shinano Kodai Shikō (信濃古代史考)|date=1990|publisher=Meicho shuppan|location=Tokyo|isbn=978-4626013637|pages=201-202}} [[File:Mononobe no Moriya.jpg|thumb|120px|[[Mononobe no Moriya]] by [[Kikuchi Yōsai]]]] [[File:Jinchoukan-Moriya-shiryoukan Jinchoukan-ura-kofun.JPG|thumb|left|The Jinchōkan-ura Kofun (神長官裏古墳) in the Moriya estate in Chino, Nagano. The 7th century tomb is linked with Mononobe no Moriya's supposed son Takemaro in family lore.]] ===Moreya, the Moriya clan and Mononobe no Moriya=== The similarity between the names of both Moreya/Moriya and the 6th century ''[[Muraji|Ōmuraji]]'' [[Mononobe no Moriya]], who opposed [[Buddhism in Japan#Asuka Period (538 to 710) and Nara Period (710–794)|the introduction of Buddhism to Japan]], had led to a long-standing conflation of the two figures (cf. Moreya being called ''Moriya Daijin'' in medieval texts). A certain legend claims that a son of Mononobe no Moriya, named either '''Takemaro''' (武麿) or '''Otogimi''' (弟君), survived the defeat of the Mononobe in the [[Soga–Mononobe conflict|Battle of Mount Shigi]] in 587 and fled to Suwa, where he married into the ''Jinchō'' Moriya clan; Takemaro is thus reckoned as a clan ancestor in the ''Jinchō Moriya-shi Keifu''.{{efn|「武麿 (一云弟君): 三十一代用命天皇御宇 物部守屋大連守屋大臣ハ饒速日命苗裔 尾輿大連ノ子爲國殞身河内國澁川館兒孫逃匿葦原或逃、亡長子雄君入美濃、次子武麿入于信濃洲羽來弖娶神氏女嗣長職。」}} A small [[kofun|mound]] in the Moriya clan's historical estate in [[Chino, Nagano|Chino]] dated to the 7th century{{cite web|title=神長官裏古墳|url=http://kofun.info/kofun/815|website=古墳マップ (Kofun Map)}} is claimed in family lore to be Takemaro's tomb.Moriya (1991). pp. 6-7. Ōwa (1990) believes this story to be modelled after the biography of Mononobe no Masara (物部麻佐良), who according to the ''Sendai Kuji Hongi'' married Imoko (妹古), the daughter of an unidentified 'Suwa-no-[[Kabane|Atai]]' (須羽直) during the reign of [[Emperor Buretsu]] in the late 5th century, yet sees it as at least being inspired by a real-life connection between the Mononobe clan and Shinano Province.Ōwa (1990). pp. 110-111. Moriya Shrine in [[Okaya, Nagano|Okaya City]] where Moreya is worshipped currently denies any connection between the god and the Mononobe chancellor.{{cite web|title=洩矢神社とは|url=https://moriyajinja.amebaownd.com/pages/738296/page_201611220733|website=洩矢神社公式HP (Moriya Shrine Official Homepage)}} ==Descendants== Moreya is held to be the ancestor of the Moriya clan (守矢氏), which traditionally served as priests of the Suwa ''Kamisha''.Rekishi REAL Henshūbu (2016). p. 40. The chief priest of the ''Kamisha'' was the ''[[Suwa clan#As ōhōri|ōhōri]]'' or ''ōhafuri'' (大祝 'great priest'), who was considered to be a [[Arahitogami|living deity]] and the embodiment of Suwa Myōjin, the god of the shrine. Assisting the ''ōhōri'' (who by tradition was a member of the [[Suwa clan]], Suwa Myōjin's supposed descendants) were five priests, at the head of which was the ''kan-no-osa'' (神長, also ''jinchō'') or ''jinchōkan'' (神長官), an office occupied by members of the Moriya clan. The ''jinchōkan'' oversaw the ''Kamisha'''s rites and ceremonies in general and summoned [[Mishaguji]] - a god or gods [[Animism|thought to inhabit rocks or trees]] worshipped in the region since ancient timesMoriya (1991), p. 4.{{cite web|title=ミシャグジ (Mishaguji)|url=http://japangod.dip.jp/%E3%83%9F%E3%82%B7%E3%83%A3%E3%82%B0%E3%82%B8.html|website=やおよろず 日本の神様辞典 (Yaorozu - Nihon no kamisama jiten)}} and regarded by the Moriya as their patron deity - to [[Spirit possession|possess]] individuals or inanimate objects during ceremonies, being the only one considered to be able to do so.Miyasaka (1987). p. 22. [[File:Jinchokan Moriya Museum.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum in [[Chino, Nagano]], built by architect [[Terunobu Fujimori]].]]It has been observed that the religious climate of Suwa is a syncretism of ancient indigenous beliefs and practices (e.g. the worship of Mishaguji) reorganized under a Yamato framework (e.g. Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata, the cult of the ''ōhōri''), but with the local element still predominant. Despite (or perhaps because of) his officially being a living god and the ''Kamisha'''s chief priest, the Suwa ''ōhōri'' - who assumed the office during childhood - had little, if any, real power or influence in the shrine's affairs, which firmly rested in the hands of the Moriya ''jinchōkan'',Oh (2011), p. 158. with his unique ability to hear Mishaguji and call upon the god(s) to descend upon someone or something and his knowledge of special rituals, which were closely guarded secrets traditionally passed down via word of mouth only to a single individual, the heir to the office of ''jinchōkan''.Moriya (1991), p. 5.Miyasaka (1987). p. 27. The establishment of [[State Shinto]] in the [[Meiji period]] abolished the tradition of hereditary succession among Shinto priests and private ownership of shrines.{{cite book|last1=Earhart|first1=H. Byron|title=Religion in Japan: Unity and Diversity|date=2013|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-1285528816|page=199|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jYAWAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA199}}{{cite book|last1=Josephson|first1=Jason Ananda|title=The Invention of Religion in Japan|date=2012|publisher=University of Chicago Press|page=150|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxzuzIszO60C&pg=PA150}}{{cite web|title=Becoming a Shintō Priest or Priestess Titles-Roles of Men & Women Serving Shrines|url=http://www.onmarkproductions.com/html/shinto-priesthood.html}} Accordingly, the shrine at Suwa passed under the control of the state, with government appointees replacing the clans who had historically served as its priests, the Suwa and the Moriya among them. As the ancient priestly offices of the shrine became defunct, most of the unwritten tradition once guarded by the Moriya ''jinchōkan'' died with the last occupant of the position. A museum dedicated to preserving information about the Moriya and documents owned by the family, the [[:ja:神長官守矢史料館|Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum]] (神長官守矢史料館 ''Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan''), currently stands on the clan estate in [[Chino, Nagano|Chino City, Nagano]].{{cite web|title=神長官守矢資料館|url=http://www.zephyr.dti.ne.jp/bushi/siseki/moriya.htm|website=武田氏の史跡探訪}}{{cite book|last1=Buntrock|first1=Dana|title=Materials and Meaning in Contemporary Japanese Architecture: Tradition and Today|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-72501-4|page=17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTzcAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA17}} ==Shrine== A single shrine to Moreya, [https://www.google.com/maps/place/%E6%B4%A9%E7%9F%A2%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE/@36.0509086,138.0340072,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x601cfe2df9abbb03:0x6da6a669d0b38dbc!8m2!3d36.0509043!4d138.0361959 Moriya Shrine] (洩矢神社 ''Moriya-jinja''), stands in [[Okaya, Nagano|Okaya City]], [[Nagano Prefecture|Nagano]], near the Tenryū River. On the opposite bank stands [https://www.google.co.jp/maps/place/%E8%97%A4%E5%B3%B6%E7%A4%BE/@36.0533034,138.0343004,85m/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xaa578226f1624a6f!8m2!3d36.0532219!4d138.0343569?hl=en Fujishima Shrine] (藤島神社 ''Fujishima-jinja''), where legend says Suwa Myōjin stood or encamped during the battle. [https://www.google.co.jp/maps/place/%E3%80%92392-0015+Nagano-ken,+Suwa-shi,+Nakasu,+%E8%97%A4%E5%B3%B6%E7%A4%BE/@36.0026973,138.1168832,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x601c565f74160f9b:0x2df0d109a200efc8!8m2!3d36.0026922!4d138.1190749 The other Fujishima Shrine] (藤島社 ''Fujishima-sha''), where the wisteria Suwa Myōjin used during the battle was supposedly planted and sprouted, is in Nakasu, [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]].{{cite web|title=藤島社・藤島大明神 諏訪市中洲神宮寺|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/hujisimasya.htm|website=八ヶ岳原人}}Miyachi (1992), pp. 91-93. ==See also== *[[Suwa taisha]] *[[Takeminakata]] *[[Mishaguji]] *[[Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba]] *[[Mononobe no Moriya]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|author1=Imai, Nogiku|title=諏訪ものがたり (Suwa Monogatari)|date=1960|publisher=Kōyō Shobō (甲陽書房)|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/9543689}} *Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum, ed. (1991). ''Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan no shiori'' (神長官守矢資料館のしおり) (Rev. ed.). {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|editor=Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai|title=古代諏訪の祭祀と氏族 (Kodai Suwa no Saishi to Shizoku)|date=2017|publisher=Ningen-sha (人間社)|isbn=978-4908627163}} {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|last1=Miyasaka|first1=Mitsuaki|title=諏訪大社の御柱と年中行事 (Suwa-taisha no Onbashira to Nenchu-gyōji)|date=1992|publisher=Kyōdo shuppansha|isbn=978-4-87663-178-0}} {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|last1=Miyachi|first1=Naokazu|title=諏訪史 第二卷 前編 (Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 1)|date=1931|publisher=Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hBVjsO2GOgC}} {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|last1=Miyachi|first1=Naokazu|title=諏訪史 第二卷 後編 (Suwa-shi, vol. 2, part 2)|date=1937|publisher=Shinano kyōikukai Suwa-bukai|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UHYSgY4lTZcC}} {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|author=Oh, Amana ChungHae|title=Cosmogonical Worldview of Jomon Pottery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hxulspIN_2UC&pg=PA157-158|date=2011|publisher=Sankeisha|isbn=978-4-88361-924-5}} *{{cite book|last1=Ōta|first1=Akira|title=諏訪神社誌 第1巻 (Suwa-jinja-shi: Volume 01)|date=1926|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/983470}} {{ja icon}} *Suwa, Enchū (1914). [http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/63 ''諏訪大明神繪詞 (Suwa-daimyōjin ekotoba)''] in Hanawa, Hoki'ichi (ed.), 続群書類従 (''Zoku Gunsho-Ruijū''). Tokyo: Zoku Gunsho-Ruijū Kanseikai. pp. 494–539. (Original work written 1356) {{ja icon}} *{{cite book|author1=Ueda, Masaaki|author2=Gorai, Shigeru|author3=Miyasaka, Yūshō|author4=Ōbayashi, Taryō|author5=Miyasaka, Mitsuaki|title=御柱祭と諏訪大社 (Onbashira-sai to Suwa-taisha)|date=1987|location=Nagano|publisher=Chikuma Shobō|isbn=978-4-480-84181-0}} {{ja icon}} ==External links== *[https://moriyajinja.amebaownd.com/ Official website of Moriya Shrine (洩矢神社公式HP)] {{ja icon}} *[http://www.city.chino.lg.jp/www/contents/1000001465000/ Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum] on [[Chino, Nagano|Chino City]]'s official website {{ja icon}} {{jmyth navbox long}} [[Category:Hunting gods]] [[Category:Japanese deities]] [[Category:Japanese mythology]] [[Category:Nature gods]] [[Category:Shinto]] [[Category:Shinto kami]]

revision.comment: Converting to use [[Template:Infobox settlement]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox landform | water = | name = Nama Karoo | other_name = | photo = Ecoregion AT1314.svg | photo_caption = A map of [[South Africa#Geography|South Africa]] showing the Nama Karoo ecoregion as defined by [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] | map = | map_width = | map_caption = | map_alt = | relief = | label = | label_position = | mark = | marker_size = | location = [[South Africa]], [[Namibia]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | coordinates_ref = | range = | area = {{convert|135600|km2|abbr=on}} | water_bodies = }} '''Nama Karoo''' is a [[xeric shrubland]] [[ecoregion]] located on the central plateau of South Africa and Namibia. It occupies most of the interior of the western half of South Africa and extends into the southern interior of Namibia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nama Karoo|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/at1314|website=Ecoregions|publisher=Worldwildlife.org|accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref>
== Climate == The climate tends to be volatile and very harsh. Droughts are frequent with rain primarily falling in the summer. Rainfall can also be varied with it fluctuating between {{convert|100|and|520|mm|in|2}} per year. Rainfall is known to be highly seasonal, peaking between December and March. It tends to decrease from the east to west and from north to south. The variability in the inter-annual rainfall also tends to increase with increasing aridity.<ref>Desmet, P.G., and R.M. Cowling. 1999. The climate of the Karoo – A functional approach. Pages 3-16 in W.R.J. Dean and S.J. Milton. The Karoo. Ecological patterns and processes. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.</ref> Temperature variations as large as {{convert|25|C-change|F-change|disp=or}} [[diurnal temperature variation|between day and night]] are common. Mean maximum temperatures in the mid-summer (January) exceeds {{convert|30|C|F}}, while mean minimum mid-winter (July) temperatures are below freezing.<ref>Werger, M.J.A. 1978. Biogeographical divisions of southern Africa. Pages 231-99 in M.J.A. Werger and W. Junk, editors. Biogeography and ecology of southern Africa. The Hague.</ref>
==See also== * [[Geography of South Africa]] *
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/at1314 World Wildlife Fund Page on Nama Karoo] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018002737/http://www.plantzafrica.com/vegetation/namakaroo.htm Nama Karoo Biome Page]
{{Regions of Africa}} {{Geography topics}} {{Physical geography topics}}
